They clearly know a thing or two about food in the way they pair ingredients most of the time but sometimes it's a miss. To some degree, I appreciate that their menu changes based on what is available, however, I don't appreciate it when I look on the menu and there is only one thing I would consider eating.

I have tried Radio Maria on visits to CU. The kitchen is inconsistent to the point you flip a coin and gamble I guess. Lunch on one trip was nothing short of inedible. Dinner one night was nice but over priced.

Radio Maria is an absolute gem. They exceed expectations for both their food as well as their beer selection (which is a big deal to me). I've been here multiple times and, though it can be pricey, the food and experience is excellent. They specialize in tapas, which is I a little unsure about the first time I was here, but they made for a divine experience. It allowed us to try multiple dishes without full  off one particular dish. So good.

Now to my favorite part, the bar. It's hard to put into words the atmosphere the bar has. The bar itself is lighted, and it's a sight to behold. The walls feature an array of different art pieces, and each one is unique. Most are like nothing I've seen before. 

I can't say enough good things about this place. No matter the occasion, Radio Maria is one of those businesses in C-U that I consider a must visit. Even if you don't go in for food (which you should) at least do yourself a favor and grab a drink at the bar and take in the view. You won't be disappointed.

My wife and I returned to Radio after not having been for several years. The service was fantastic and the wine list was excellent. For the most part, the food was good, but there were a couple clunkers. 

We ordered the a number of tapas, including arancini, pork belly arepa, diver scallops, crab tart, pork tacos, and beignets. The arancini were nicely done, if slightly overpowered by the breading. The pork belly arepa, however, was not made with pork belly and the diver scallops were not diver scallops. I believe the arepa was made with pork shoulder, and was good, but no one ever said anything about the change. Similarly, the scallops were very well done, but were not diver scallops. The crab tart, on the other hand, was a clunker, as were the beignets. The tart was made of corn bread and I don't know that I've ever had a more dried out piece of corn bread in my life. It totally overshadowed the crab. The beignets were huge, which meant they weren't cooked through. They were like eating a heavy cake doughnut, not the light crunchy wonder they should be. The best dish of the night was the tacos. Smoky, spicy, delicious. We will probably go back, but will be much more careful in selecting our dishes.

This place keeps getting better and better. I have to admit, it had been 3 years since I went back to Champaign but I am glad we were able to visit one of the restaurants I used to frequent. The tapas bar wasn't there when I used to come, but it is an excellent addition to this fusion style restaurant. My favorites were the egg plant frittes and the seared scallops. Hopefully it won't be another 3 years until I am back!

We had a nice dinner here last night. We were seated quickly, and the service was great. We had such a nice waiter, a self proclaimed foodie, and each of his suggestions were great. My only complaint would be how the menu was organized. It was very difficult to read, as I have never taken Spanish nor any of my table-mates. It took us quite some time to realize this was a tapas bar! Lovely seared tuna and beef tenderloin with horseradish mashed potatoes.

Brunch!

OK, first, we have to discuss the breakfast potatoes.  As a daughter of Irish stock, I thought I was pretty much over any potato-creation.  Wrong.  These were baked to perfection (crispy skin, soft middles) and impeccably seasoned.  I ate every last morsel.  Seriously, I love when things look so simple (they are just cut-up potatoes!) are so unreasonably delicious.

Secondly, just about any option could be made vegetarian.  Bonus points for that, Maria!

Portions were enormous... but we all cleaned our plates... so yeah, it was all very good (or we are all brunch-piggies, your pick).

Our lovely brunch was reasonably priced as well.  I treated my two friends (yeah, I'm a high roller) without cringing at the check.

What has happened to this place???!!! The brunch quality has decreased steadily and the overall service is terrible. On Friday night, our table was approached 3 times and asked if we wanted a waiter or if we would lime to order our drinks from the bar, we requested waiter, and waited another 20 minutes. They were pouring martinis into snifter glasses because they ran out of martini glasses??? This place has always been my steady place, hopefully they figure before they get swallowed by the new competition in downtown.

This place should be shut down. The incompetence of the staff here is embarrassing. Two tables next to us left even before getting their first plate served after 2 hours of waiting. When we asked about the estimate of our food, the waitress very impolitely responded "there are other tables that have been waiting for longer than you guys have". This restaurant is a disgrace to the beautiful and beloved campus town.

The food was great, a great meal with a variety of menu items. I had went this past Saturday on Mom's Weekend at UIUC. I felt that they were a little understaffed for an event like this that brings them an intense amount of traffic. They could not properly accommodate my large party which they had previously told that they would be able to sit us all near each other. Upon arriving they told us we could have two separate tables in completely different rooms or wait for a bigger party to be done and take one of their tables. We decided to wait, and when the other party was done, we tried to get a table and the staff was rude saying that we could not take it. Eventually the staff member talked to a manager and we ended up getting the table. 

Great food, service needs work.

We went at 1130 on a Sunday morning for brunch. Party of 5, the wait was only a few minutes although the restaurant was crowded. Our hostess was very nice and placed us in a good comfortable table with plenty of room to get in and move around. We all had either an omelette or French toast or the special. Aaron was our server and he was awesome, quick, funny, attentive and had great ideas about what to eat. I ordered the lobster omelette and it was very good, light meal with vegetables. I asked to substitute fruit for potatoes and Aaron was very accommodating. My only complaint is that the Bloody Mary was weak. Aaron and the people who served us were great, they kept our waters full. The other folks at our table enjoyed their meals. AAA establishment.

Nice upscale-casual place in the heart of downtown Champaign. Their menu varies, but just tonight I tried a couple of tapas (fried mozzarella and calamari) and the mushroom ravioli. All were delicious and well presented.

My warm chocolate cake dessert, however, tasted soggy and generally unpleasant. It came with a scoop of some oddly flavored ice cream---I think it was meant to be mint, but it tasted more like horseradish. Not the best way to end a dinner; fortunately the rest of the meal was good enough to make up for it.

Our server tonight did a thoroughly wonderful job. But overall service in the restaurant felt slightly slow, even on this quiet Monday night when my party was one of only two or three in the entire restaurant for a whole two hours. Halfway through our meal I noticed a middle-aged woman abruptly exit the restaurant despite pleas from her waiter. There was no commotion: it appeared the customer left, after settling down but before ordering, simply to protest the service speed.

If I had to nitpick, I'd add that the men's restroom was a little worn and unkempt in the details for a restaurant of this caliber. The lock was also broken. Holistically, though, I had a great dining experience here.

Quick tip to first-time diners: Free parking is kitty-corner to the restaurant in a third-party lot. Spaces numbered 1 through 30 are reserved for this restaurant's patrons.

Honestly, this place is not even worth trying *for dinner*, so just steer clear of it. My family and I have tried it multiple times (we live in the area) and it's never been good. 

For example, tonight we tried the paella, the Biahi Tuna, and the Torta Maria. The meat in the paella was tasteless, the rice was undercooked, and there were small patches of dirt or sand (possibly from the mussels?) in the rice which made it kind of gross to eat. The Biahi Tuna had sliced almonds on it that were hard as rocks, and the Torta Maria was a gloppy mess with unidentifiable ingredients. And here's the kicker - each dish was also super pricey! 

Although our server was very friendly and helpful, I still only give this place one star.

first drink: arcadia porter.  pretty good.  decent price.

second drink: kilt lifter. menu advertises: "tastes like a cookie".  ok i'm in the mood for sweet.  

when i got it and tasted it:  EWWUCK.  completely flat.  and tasted like syrup.  not the you-put-on-your-pancakes-good-kind, but the high-fructose-corn-syrup-kind.  EWWUCK.

me: can i trade this for something else?  it's really not good.
bartender 1: what do you mean?
bartender 2: what is going on here.
me: this tastes like corn syrup.
bartender 2: the menu says "tastes like a cookie"
me: it tastes like ROBITUSSIN. have you tried it.
bartender 2 walks away never to return
bartender 1: we can't _trade_ it. it's not like we can serve it to someone else.  it would be different if there was something wrong with it.

this beer tastes like ROBITUSSIN; how wrong do you have to get?  

your beer tastes like ROBITUSSIN = WRONG.  your cookie tastes like ROBITUSSIN = WRONG.  anything besides ROBITUSSIN tasting like ROBITUSSIN = WRONG.

if i wanted to treat my nasal congestion, cough, runny nose, stuffy nose, sneezing, itchy watery eyes, i would have gone to my local pharmacy.  but hey, at least i got a better deal at radio maria's.

it's not entirely their fault; it's my fault for being born as a _non-priviledged_, seeing that i'm not a WHITE MAN donning a business suit.  

if you want differential treatment, go here.

In Champaign, this is the closest thing to a Spanish or Latin American style tapas-and-wine experience. The tapas are great, though generally quite small for what you pay. Favorites: queso de cabra frito (fried goat cheese), bread and butter (comes with several flavored butters), patatas (potatoes), calamari, and eggplant frittes. The wine selection is excellent, too.
Delicious, loved the tapas and the paella. Very good food, a little pricey but worth it for a nice dinner out

I've moved back to Champaign-Urbana after living here briefly 8 years ago and sooo much has changed. I feel like either the town finally realized that it would be wise to start spiffing its image up a bit to attract more students' $$  by spending some $$ or else maybe in the last 8 years, CU's been adopted by a millionaire benefactor with desire to see a small town emulate a big bad city in its gastric offerings. The restaurant scene here has improved phenomenally. My boyfriend and I popped into Radio Maria after being turned away from Bacaro for not having a reservation on a Saturday night. We both had to giggle a little as that's never happened to either of us before in Chicago but it's good to get rejected every now and then. The waitress was apologetic and nice enough about it. So next door to Radio it was and I'm so glad we gave it a chance. We hadn't been in the mood for tapas until we opened the menu. Surprisingly innovative, interesting and very hip. We tried the smoked red potatoes with aioli, the fire roasted pears with manchego shavings and fennel, spanish fusilli pasta salad with olives (which I didn't want to fuss with at first b/c I hate spitting out seeds in public but they were pitted, nice touch) and spanish olive oil. I'm not a big dessert person but since I'd been enjoying the meal so much, I splurged and ordered the pumpkin cheesecake with cinnamon cream sauce. Still thinking about it a day later...the restaurant's decor was again surprisingly hip for Champaign. The bar is lit in blue from beneath and the artwork was very urban/Japanese. There was this cool light box banner thing running the length of the artfully splash-painted brick walls that I'd love to have in our house back in Chicago. Check it out if you're in town. The waitstaff and service was also very friendly, young and attentive.

I went here for Valentine's Day and was slightly disappointed. While the soft lighting and tiled ceiling lends a lovely ambiance, the food and service did not stand up. 

It was a very busy night, but our waitress was obviously assigned to too many tables. It too a long time for her to take our order and she forgot to bring the basket of chips initially. We were also seated by the window and the heating was poor. I was lucky I was wearing a warm dress, because I saw people near us having to wear their jackets while dining. 

I enjoyed my appetizer of figs with honey and gouda and the chips had a tasty aioli dip, but the main courses were less impressive. I had the Torta Maria, which sounded fascinating, but it ended up being a heap of flavors that really didn't stand out. My date's chicken breast was teeny tiny and he did not enjoy the accompanying slaw. The dessert menu was a bit boring, but the pot de creme was good. 

I also tried the tapas bar recently, which was a slightly better experience. The salmon skewers with cucumber were perfectly spiced and delectable. The balsamic fruit with manchego on bread was good as well. However, the lamb skewers...they were like meatloaf on a stick. The tapas are a good way to try several dishes, but they are overpriced considering how little you get and that I could probably grill salmon and put it on a stick myself. The exception would have been if the little dishes displayed exceptional artistry, such as Cafe Luna's.

This is probably the best place to take your parents/family out for Sunday brunch, especially if your family is full of food snobs who don't believe small college towns have anything worth eating. C-U does a good job of disproving this (and at times, an amazingly disgusting job of proving it correct) but Radio Maria is my number one choice.

Their brunch menu features typical brunch/breakfast items; omelettes (lots of options for fillings), other egg creations, sandwiches, etc. My mom is a big fan of their crab cakes, and I believe my dad always gets a sandwich of some kind. I always get an omelette, which I always enjoy. Everything (nearly) comes served with their "beer bread" which seems to be some kind of beer/corn bread thing that's fantastic. They sell it separately in loaves, last time we were there my parents bought one to take home.

The service can be a bit iffy, last time we went our waiter seemed to have forgotten about us as people who were seated later got their food way before we did. But eventually our food came, and he was very apologetic. I don't think this is indicative of their service typically, but from what others have said it may be. 

Overall though, Radio Maria is not to be missed.

Radio Maria really is a bright spot in downtown Champaign. It's sort of criminal that its average rating isn't higher (particularly compared to duller visits like the unremarkable Esquire's and Applebeesian Destihl).

While there may be little in Champaign to compare to bigger-city fine dining, Radio Maria (and Bacaro, to a more intimate extent) shoot pretty satisfyingly close to the mark. Radio's selection of beer and spirits is dizzying and its bartenders have been, in my experience, charming and skilled. Their tapas menu is a little uneven, but with that topography come some nice peaks.

For sit-down dinners, there's a dining area and outside seating, both of which are quite nice. The dinner menu is small but far more evenly excellent. Their desserts are also wonderful. Other restaurants in the area with comparable pricing can't deliver meals this nice.

And finally, go to Radio Maria for brunch. You'll spend about as much as you might at, say, "Le Peep," but your meal will be ten times as good. Getting there at 10:30 on a weekend morning and sitting outside off North Walnut Street is a pleasure unique to Champaign, and it's one I'll miss when I'm gone.

I'm a huge fan of tapas.  I love going with 2-3 people and ordering way too much food in order to try as much as possible.  Well this trip I accomplished just that.  I came here with 3 others and we each ordered 2-3 items off the menu.

Everything that came out was good.  There was nothing we tried that was bad, but a couple stood out above the rest.  Here are the items we got!

The Brussels Sprouts were delicious!  I highly recommend you order these if you come.

The Risotto cakes were the table favorite although they were good but not AMAZING for me.

The Cheese Plate was presented nicely and had good cheeses, but far too expensive for what you get honestly.  You can skip this.

Fried Cauliflower/Broccoli was delicious!  I highly recommend this.  Comes with an aioli that you may want to go easy on as I felt my arteries clogging a bit with every bite.

Fried Potatoes they have come as 3 different options.  We chose the one with cheese, andouille sausage, and a fried egg which were delicious, but I'm a sucker for fried egg on anything really.

Fried Goat Cheese sounded good on paper and was fine, but I could have gone without it.  This one is a pass for me on the next trip.

Paella we chose was the mixed which came with andouille sausage, shrimp, chicken and mussels.  I liked it but it did not compare to the Paella's of Miami.  Also keep in mind that this Paella is tiny and definitely more of an individual portion rather than a shareable.


All in all I was happy to try this place and would come back if someone was dying to go back.

Staff and kitchen are responsive to dietary requirements, but there are few gluten-free, vegetarian options and zero vegan options.

For this meal I went alt-veg to include dairy and egg (I have no idea why unborn chicken embryos are included in vegetarianism, but apparently it's a thing...)

My husband and I visited this popular spot for Sunday Brunch and tried three menu items. We came here mostly for the drink specials: bottomless mimosas ($15) and make-your-own bloody mary.
The mimosas were truly excellent. Try the guava! But bottomless mimosas need to be served quickly and that was not the case here. We spent more time waiting for mimosas than we did drinking them, although our server did his best and finally just stared bringing more without asking. I wish this deal was $12.99 (max) instead of $15.
The bloody mary bar was way too much fun! Plenty of fixings and sauces to add in. The house mix was standard and worked well with the extras.

1. Vegetarian Masa Boat Surprise: Scrambled egg with peppers, onions, mushrooms, and cheese atop a cornbread slice sitting on black beans, with corn tortillas on the side. Surprise! There was also cream cheese between the cornbread and scrambled egg mix. I was confused by the use of the cornbread as it made the dish dry and served as an additional grain/starch when paired with tortillas. But if you're going for a filling egg-based dish that's rather tasty due to its animal components (including cheese), then go for it and you won't be disappointed.

2. Falafel Salad: I've had better falafel. This falafel was dry and flavorless, plus I  think it was a bit overcooked. The pickled onions were a nice touch, and the pita bread slices were flavorful, but on the whole this dish was rather boring. The yogurt was too minty.

3. Carrot Cake Pancakes: Great carrot cake flavor and a delightful cream cheese frosting-syrup. Make sure you have a bit of the fresh strawberries with each bite - their tartness plays well with the cakes and syrup. One of the cakes was overcooked and black on the bottom, making the cake hard to cut and affecting the overall flavor.

Our brunch experience at this hipster joint  cost $60 plus tip, and yet I could have caught more of a buzz from the drink specials. I might end up here again, but I won't be chomping at the bit for another try.
Great vegetarian options and large beer selection! Highly recommend! Heard there was salsa dancing in the evening on Saturdays as well, but left before it started.

I had a great experience. The food and drinks were great. The ambience was great. The waitress was very attentive to the party. Very eclectic and interesting food and drink choices. Especially the Tapas.

Soooooo, I love Radio Maria. I have loved it for years. I have seriously been frequenting this place for over a decade. And while it has been clear to me for quite sometime that the quality of my experience here has been on the decline, I've been in denial... until today. Sunday brunch is tradition for me and a handful of my girlfriends. We literally do it in some form every weekend. Today we went and well... where should I start? Our waiter was completely aloof. We waited at least 10 minutes, in a moderately busy bar for a whiskey soda (don't judge us for loving whiskey. It's always 5pm on Sunday Funday). No biggie though. My steak and poached eggs were not hot when delivered to my table. No biggie though. But when one of my girlfriends ordered a salad with slide of shrimp and was brought 2 shrimp ... like what?? (Look at the picture!) In what restaurant world is this ok? $3 for 2 shrimp? They should have brought her 3 oz of shrimp (an actual serving) for whatever the cost. But 2 shrimp? Don't be petty. That's so petty, and as much as I love Radio brunch when it is done right, I think I need my space until they get it together. Mind you I'm still annoyed they gave up their late night menu but that's another post for another day...

Best unique and fancy restaurant I've been to in downtown champaign. Service was excellent. Interior decor was vintage/very dark (the more difficult it is to see your food, the more expensive the restaurant lol). Their cuisine was called "new American" so not belonging to any type of food, but more like a fusion. Ex. They serve a variety of things from paella, duck roast, ahi tuna, etc. fancy plating. You're probably going to spend average $25+ per entree. It's tapas style so the portions are very small for what you pay for. Overall, I'd go there again to try their brunch.

The food was delicious. I had the carrot cake pancakes. Yum. People at my table loved their eggs. Though I had a side of potatoes and they were cooked well done. Many of them were too hard to pick up with a fork. 

Negative: We ordered when there was barely anyone in the restaurant so there is no excuse that we had to wait OVER AN HOUR for our food. I was SOOO hungry by the time it came!!!!
I went for brunch and got the migas dish. It was very flavorful. I really liked the table and overall interior decorations- very old-timey and vintage. I would definitely come again!

As I waited over 15 minutes for the waitress to return with my initial drink order on a slow night, I hoped the tonic wasn't as flat and flavorless as the last time. It was. I ordered a Bell's HopSlam the next moment I saw the waitress, and it came only 5 minutes after I pained through the flat gin and tonic. When the tapas came 45 after my wife and I arrived, we enjoyed the mussel in miso broth special and bacon-wrapped rainbow trout with aoili. The Spanish tortilla was burnt. Luckily, the harissa helped cover up the carcinogens. Now, I wait for the waitress to return so I can ask for the bill and go to a bar with responsive service. At least it's beautiful outside.

Had the chance to visit this restaurant on a Sunday night.  Despite having seated most of the tables in the bar side of the restaurant, they seemed to have only one person actively waiting the tables.  It took 10-15 minutes to get our drinks...not cocktails, but diet coke and iced tea.  The waitress was friendly enough when she showed up to the table, but seemed relatively uninterested in doing so.
We ordered several items from the tapas menu (no entrees) and other tables that were seated after us received their food before we did.  I agree with the reviewer below that says that tapas should be brought out as they are prepared, not all at once.  But sure enough, 45 minutes later all our food arrives at once.
The food itself was all very good to excellent, but in hindsight it's the too cool for school attitude of the waitstaff that stands out in my mind, not the food.  That's a shame.

This place is a paradox. I was there over Memorial Day weekend, on Saturday night, and had none of the issues with staff "coolness" that others reported. We were treated well and served professionally as we stayed all evening (7-11 PM). The drinks were good, though I'd say the beer was a bit small for the otherwise fair price. The odd thing is that the food is irrationally high priced - at least for the entrees. Our group of 4 ordered 3 of the specials and 1 menu item. The specials (which are not priced on the board) were simple plates of an entree & a "decorative" side. I ordered the Paella from the menu. The Paella was a 6 inch skillet of rice and seafood - 3 or so pieces each of shrimp and scallops, with some hard cooked sausage slices throughout. Good, but not special. Two of the specials were a fillet with a garlic crust - 4 oz of good meat. So what's the issue? Well $30 for the fillet and $24 for the Paella is an outrage for a remodeled VFW in a College town. This pricing is just too much like Soho/Manhattan - but it is Central Illinois! So go for the drinks and the Salsa Dancing after 10:30, but skip the food - it just is not worth it.

If you don't know where to brunch with friends on a Sunday, go to Radio Maria. Their brunch menu is unique and has a vast array of options; so bring your vegetarian, pescatarian, or omnivorous friends.
Their freshly juiced beverages are on point, and they even have guava juice! This is the only restaurant around the Champaign area I know of that has guava juice!
I ordered the smoked salmon eggs benedict and it was savory, delicious, and juicy.
Staff are super friendly and 10/10 will come back.

I'm a huge fan of Radio Maria, but their Valentine's Day Dinner left a very bad taste in my mouth and it wasn't the food.  Radio Maria is my favorite restaurant in Champaign.  The food is top-notch and the atmosphere is one of a kind.  But my wife and I had their Valentine's day menu this past weekend.  The food was great, but not for the outrageous cost.  It was $50/person plus drinks for a "tasting" menu that wouldn't have filled up a mouse.  Normally the value/price ratio is excellent.  I always felt like the food was worth the cost, but not the valentine's day fixed menu.  The high price combined with lack luster service took the sizzle out of what could have been a hot night.

I can't speak for the bar and restaurant itself. We went to a wedding party where the party closed the place for the evening.

As a party venue, Radio Maria was really great. I love the old architecture and the period decorations. Yet, they have a modern touch also, so I guess you would call it eclectic. When you walk in, the bar is is front of you. It is large, and I would guess that it is very well attended. (Lots of people tried to get in but were turned away due to the party.) They had one of the largest liquor selections I've seen, and they even have infused liquors. I tried the maple-bacon burbon - good, but a little too sweet for my tastes. Their infused liquors are all made on premises. The bartender told me he did it himself - and for the party, he wore a kilt.

The dining room is large. We had a limited menu with four choices and we all pre-ordered our meals. I have to say that the salad served before the dinner was really excellent, fresh, simple and just the right amount of dressing. I can't say as much for the meal - I had smoked ribs. They were pretty tough, but did have a good taste.

They also have tables on the sidewalk which we took advantage of. Topping the night off by sitting outside, drinking bourbon, eating dessert, smoking a cigar and watching the people walk by ended the night with a flair.

If I make it back to Champaign, Radio Maria is definitely on my go-to list.

Sunday brunch is the best in town, in my opinion.  Portions are generous and the entrees are flavorful and hearty.  Options for vegetarians.  Evening tapas is good, but Radio Maria's brunch is what won me over -- and very reasonably priced -- about $10 including coffee.

I went with a friend and sat outside. It was a beautiful night and our server was very personable and helpful. 

She helped us order some things that she thought we would like based on savory and sweet and she didn't mind repeating specials and such for us.

We got three tapas and an entree and it was all great.

A bunch of people told us to try the plantains. They were our least favorite. They weren't bad... just plain.

We also got the fried goat cheese, which was served with a honey sauce and bread, and arancini, mozzarella-stuffed risotto. They were both excellent. 

We had their gnocchi special which was absolutely delicious. It was definitely worth the trip.

It is definitely a more casual place. The servers weren't around every minute, but I really didn't mind. It is pricier, but worth the money. I think that it is a great place to relax and spend some time with some great food.

Sunday afternoon it was empty?  Seated indoors front and center. Nice place to people watch street traffic. Ordered cocktails , mango mimosa and Bloody Maria. Expecting mimosa to be well chilled it was not although both were well balanced and very tasty. Ordered tapas salsa and tortilla chips,  Coles de bruselas -pan seared Brussels sprouts with bacon bits and malt vinegar aioli , Bistec - hangar steak with roasted potatoes ,asparagus and artichokes atop unidentified spicy white sauce. Food arrived not piping hot but acceptable. Taste was at the apex of my tasting abilities. Caramelization of the veggies was spot on.  Seasoning was all well balanced , nothing overpowering yet an assertive complimentary addition to the innate flavors of the meats and vegetables.

The tapas and drinks at the bar are great. I highly recommend their small plates as well. I have had their shrimp, steak and scallops before and they were excellently cooked. All the cocktails I have tried from here have been great and when I have had trouble what to drink, the bartender's recommendations were right on point (after describing to him the tastes I like in drinks). Their main dishes and their brunch was underwhelming and disappointing. I would just come here for cocktails and tapas as I mentioned before.

I actually came here for the first time ever last week, but it was a long time coming. I kept hearing such good things about Radio Maria from what seemed like everyone I knew, so I couldn't wait to finally try it out. I went for Saturday Brunch, and was so impressed! 

They have a make-your-own bloody mary bar, with so many toppings. You can also opt to make your Bloody Mary with tequila (which they call Bloody Maria). Friends I was with got mimosas, and they had a handful of different flavors of those as well. 

Their brunch menu items are so delicious. They have omelets, breakfast burritos, and more. Radio Maria is spanish like the name suggests, so their items were definitely not the typical American breakfast items, but that's definitely not a bad thing. It was great. 

I can't wait to go back for brunch! I also want to go for a daytime meal as well, to try out those dishes. The atmosphere of the restaurant is really unique and cool too. Highly recommend.

Stunning!
Astounding interior!
Amazing Bar!

Look at the bar - the rail is a retired escalator handrail.  Look above the bar, and you can see the shroud from a vane axial fan - a big one, from the former University of Illinois wind tunnel.  Even the host station is a re-purposed tube radio.  The center of the bar is a drink dispenser, made from a re-purposed laser.  Gad - there was so much eye-candy, I had a blast!

The tapas is simply amazing - every dish we ordered was good.  The prices were on par for what you pay in downtown Champaign, and my daughter was smart enough to get us reservations.  If you're bold enough to try a walk in, all I can say is good luck.  They are reserved to the hilt usually.

All in all, a good meal.  We have eaten here twice, and love the place.

We came here for Sunday brunch, and ordered 3 things.

Leroy's buttermilk skillet cornbread @ $4 - just one slice.  [Chicago downtown's Bandera Restaurant used to have a whole mini skillet for this price 5x the portion of this, the price has since gone up.]  With the word "skillet", we assumed it would came in a full skillet (even a small one, but nope!)  Taste-wise nothing to write home about, the bread is just so-so.  Marmalade added a nice kick to it though.

Migas & Pulled Pork Eggs benedict - both were not too bad each came with a small side of their house potatoes.  The deep fried house potatoes were delish. Portions of the main entree were enough, but the side potatoes was on the lighter side, almost too little.  

Service at 1:30 pm on a Sunday was a little slow - the place was fairly filled up, still, it seemed like they had a good number of servers, so this was a little disappointing.  

Nice ambient, but can get very noisy.  

Our overall rating of the restaurant is 2-star.

i'm from los angeles, the land of many-a-radio maria - so really, i like radio maria because it feels like a slice of home.  i've been three times so far, and frankly i have to say that nothing has blown me away, but everything i've had has been pretty damn solid.

first time i came for lunch, and had a portobella/goatcheese/pesto sandwich thing, and it was delicious.  not very unique but good eats.  i came for dinner the same night and enjoyed the pan seared peppercorn crusted tuna which again was not a unique dish by any means but solidly executed.  i recently went back for the tapas - their piquillos rellenos were flavorful and the portobello entree was perfect.  what i admire about the food here is that they aren't scared of flavor, which is something ive noticed happening in fusion-type restaurants.  ALSO, their drinks are marvelous. pricey but innovative!

Radio Maria is normally good but I had the worst experience here and will not be going back. Our server said the kitchen lost our ticket but we still didn't get our food for an hour and a half. Then when we did it was clear they had skimped portions to get us our food faster. I had a lobster eggs Benedict with lobster on only one eggs. And my friend had a vegetarian eggs Benedict but the egg was poached. They gave us a 25% discount but not worth it
Great, unique food. Awesome atmosphere. The hummus is fantastic, as is the goat cheese with honey.

There are so many good things to say about Radio Maria. Their style is a marriage between old world 50's and the 21st century. The tables are decorated underneath and they are unique to every table. There are about 10 tables outside if you like sitting outdoors. 

The brunch menu may seem overwhelming at first, but you can narrow it down to your dish pretty easily. They have a wide selection of omelets. They also have egg dishes with rice and beans. It includes vegetarian options. I had the guava juice, churros, and smoked pork posole. It hit the spot. Try getting a slice of beer bread! It's hearty and is flavorful. The churros are fluffy and not too sweet. I am not familiar with real churros, but this one tasted good! The service for a Sunday brunch is slow. I had to flag the waiter down to take our order after 15 minutes of sitting and waiting. 

The tapas menu is extensive. Hands down, my favorite dish to order are the lamb meatballs. They are made with pinenuts and tender lamb and then are stewed in a seasoned tomato sauce. You have to try them! I also love the Paella. There are several different kinds, but I like the mixed because you get to try all the different seafood and meats. It is big, so plan on sharing or gorging yourself in awesomeness. 

It is on the pricey side, so I would make this the place to go when you want to treat yourself.

Tapas Bar! Sat at the bar with a friend and the bar tender was AWESOME! He was so nice and let us try a bunch of wines until we liked one. The ambiance was great because it was dark with cool lighting. It was open late which worked because it's a quiet town. Highly recommend this place!

Good food from a wide selection of ethnicities - cajun, indian, latin american, but not fusion.  Just all on the same menu.  Kind of hard to explain.  They have just about everything - seafood, duck, lamb, plus the standards.  They try to be inventive but usually are not too adventurous - still, the meal satisfies.  I think they could let their hair down a little more by putting some riskier things on the menu.  Good selection of wines and beers, plus margarias and sangria.
Only had a couple tapas here one time, but they were good. Brunch was awesome though. Small menu but so delicious. In summer you can sit outside and it is something I will definitely repeat.

Came here for dinner and would probably go back now that I've picked a few items that I like. We did tapas, so here' s rundown.

Likes
Fried artichoke hearts
Arancini (favorite!)
Charcuterie


So-so
Grilled hanger steak
Salmon
Raw and roasted apple salad

It was very cold where we were sitting (not near the main door) and we kept feeling a draft. The staff was friendly but not memorable. 

Some of the items I felt were well-priced ($5-8). Yet, I felt others were very overpriced ($13 for basically four bites of salmon).

I just finished dinner here about an hour ago, and I'm still wondering how Radio Maria managed to get all of this attention.  I guess their HUGE wine/beer/drink list was pretty impressive, but the food...was not.  My first disappointment was in the size of the menu.  I looked it up online and they seemed to have a wide array of choices, when I saw the actual menu, I think there were 5 entree choices, in addition to a wide variety of tapas.  On top of that, the one dish I wanted, was sold out, so I went with the Smoked Duck and Brie Pizza.  I mean, it was OK, there was a good amount of duck on the pizza but the whole time I was craving more brie!!  They could have seriously doubled the amount of brie on the pizza and it still might not have been enough, I could hardly taste it.  Also, it wasn't really a pizza at all, more like a cold flatbread, so be forewarned.  I also ordered a small side salad.  It was a delicious spinach salad, but lived up to the "small" definition....AND it was $6--give me a break.  If I'm looking to drink, maybe I'll stop by next time I'm in town, but I'll hit up K.O. Fusion or Jim Gould over this place ANY day!

Radio Maria is trying a little too hard to be trendy, décor-wise--it's the kind of place you walk into and expect to be treated with a bit of a condescending attitude by the staff. But thankfully this was not the case! We made our way to the bar where we were greeted by a friendly barman who presented us with a very nice cocktail list while we waited for a table. I chose the Dark and Stormy, which was ridiculously delicious with fresh ginger grated into it! (I ended up having another that I really didn't need, just because it was so refreshingly awesome.) Unfortunately Radio Maria's website seems to be down currently and it was about two weeks ago that I went here on a trip out to Des Moines so my memory has faded as to the specifics of what we had, but we ordered off the tapas menu and everything was above average. I'd definitely return here on a trip to the Twin City area.

I grabbed brunch here this Saturday and it has been one of the most delicious ones in a long time.  I got the grilled salmon egg benedict with bottomless mimosas. The mimosas were refilled promptly and i guess blood orange is my favorite flavor.  The egg benedict was delicious but the quantity of house fries could be increased considering its price. But i must say the house fries were crispy the right amount.  The benedicts didn't fill me up so we got a plate of strawberry and cream pancakes as well. The pancakes were incredibly buttery and decadent.  10/10 would go back again especially for those benedicts or to try out them beer breads!!

My lobster eggs benedict came with a portion of lobster smaller than my thumb, as did my friend's. Both of our poached eggs were extremely undercooked which was unpleasant to eat. Furthermore, the brunch entree was supposed to come with a side of potatoes. My friend got a good serving of potatoes but I genuinely only got five cubes, which was less than half of what he got. The waitress spilled water on my foot when refilling my glass, I saw another waiter spill half a cup of coffee he was taking to a customer outside and still served it to him. We asked how much bottomless mimosas cost and were told it was $7.50 but then got charged $20 for it. When I pointed this out to the waiter, he simply said "no, it is $20" without an apology for the misinformation. 

We were here on Sunday May 20 at 10:30am and it was not very busy, so I'm not sure why the service and food were of such poor quality. Will not return to this joke of an establishment.

Food was good, not excellent. Prices seem high for the quantity and quality you get. The bar and wait staff could all really use a lesson on wine - I believe I overheard 4 staff persons who could not respond on their own to questions about wine. Fun atmosphere and decor.
The sangria here is awful. I think it was a tequila sunrise. The food is greasy and not in a good way. The only thing good was the goat cheese. But it is goat cheese. How can you mess that up?

Did they forget about an entire part of the building?  They have a restaurant that is open and functioning, and yet the food is terrible and only gets worse.  The tapas menu has changed but not for the better.
Sadly, I am pretty much O-V-E-R this place until I hear they've made some effort to serve quality food they had been for the past decade.

i would give this place 3.5 stars.  we had reservations here for sat night at 745 and weren't seated for about 15-20 minutes.  it was graduation wknd, so there were a ton of people.  when we were finally seated, we could only get seats at the bar, which was super loud.

the menu here is not big.  we started w/ the patatas and the bulgogi summer roll.  i thought it was weird that they had korean items on the menu, b/c there was also a korean hot pot dish that looked a bit like bibimbap.  the patatas were really good and smokey.

for my entree, i had the snapper w/ shitake mushrooms, edamame, and celery.  it was really light and asiany.  my brother's filet was huge, and my mom said her salmon was good.  my dad had the ratatouille w/ couscous, which was the smallest dish.  all the other portions were pretty hefty.  

for dessert, we got the tres leches cake, which was good, but i wished it was more drenched in milk.

service here is pretty fast considering it is packed and loud.  there were a ton of drinks on the menu and a bunch of beers on tap.
The food was overpriced, the service was disappointing, and the portions were small. I feel like that summarizes this restaurant adequately. Better places out there. ESPECIALLY for mexican food.

Had a really great time here with friends. We had about 8 people in our party. We started off with some drinks. I tried the cucumber Coolin' which was very refreshing. Got the Torta maria for the my entree and it was delicious. Its stuffed with sweet potato so just a heads up. I asked them to bring out the vanilla sauce on the side and told them to just top off my torta with their red sauce alone. I also asked them for some sour cream on the side to add on the torta. Our server Sacramento was awesome! He was super helpful and really friendly. Would def go back here again!

Took my friend and mother here for moms weekend brunch - service was very quick and friendly. 

Ordered an omelette, eggs Benedict, and egg sandwich. 

Everything was fresh and delicious, large portions. 

Beer bread was excellent, as were the mango mimosas! Would absolutely go back

Their paella is amazing. Lord....those big, beautiful scallops. 

Also had the on their brunch menu. The eggs Benedict with mahi mahi. The former, beautifully prepared. The fish, meh...lost its moisture somewhere, and I'm a snob when it comes to overly dried/cooked meats. But everything else on that plate, including the cornbread slice were lovely.

I really need to try their tapas and meats. I have a feeling I'm gonna bump this up to four stars when I do that!

Either Sunday nights aren't staffed with the best crew or their dinner has gone downhill since I visited regularly for work trips years ago. The patatas were fine, nothing special. The grilled Caesar had no indication of being grilled as at other restaurants- not warm, no grill marks and I had a big chunk of anchovy in my bite. If you want to leave it in the salad, make it obvious as other restaurants do so a customer can choose to put it in their mouth if desired. The shrimp tapas dish was okay but the shrimp size is unusually small for a restaurant dish- like they're cutting corners to save money.   The fundido was also fine but looks like something a college kid would mix up and microwave in their dorm with 2 cans. It was served with round chips that are probably the generic brand of a grocery store, nothing you'd expect at a restaurant. For our sangria, the bartender filled our glasses nearly full of orange juice from a bottle (maybe Tropicana) and then sprayed something from the gun into it to make it murky/cloudy. It didn't seem to have wine in it and was horrible, so we sent it back and the server said the manager took $5 off our check which didn't cover one sangria. I woke up in the middle of the night and tossed my cookies.

Excellent choice. Great and tasty tapas menu with a wide beer selection. Good service that isn't in your face.

Highly recommend the pita chips and hummus. The chips were thick, crispy on the outside, but preserving the soft tender pita texture on the inside, complimenting the exceptionally smooth hummus.

Went for dinner with a party of 3. I had made reservations but they happened to be unnecessary, since we went at a very quiet time. (But for brunch? Make them!) 

We had the friendliest and most cheerful server I've ever met, and he was extremely accommodating. 

I ordered the jalapeño cheese dip with chips and the pork shoulder tacos for my tapas. My husband got the beets, garlic shrimp, and crimini mushrooms. My mother-in-law got a vegetarian torta dish that sorta looked like a Spanish version of lasagna. 

Everything was phenomenal. (I also tried a seasonal cocktail of raspberry lemonade that was perfectly tart and sweet.)

The server informed us they smoke all of their own meat, and you can tell. Everything tasted fresh and was presented nicely. 

Even the coffee was flavorful and rich. Many times, restaurants will wimp out with weak coffee. As a coffee snob, I was pleased even getting a cup of decaf with the flourless chocolate cake was worth it. 

Fabulous local gem!

A great salsa dancing club in the evening hours!  I've never been here for lunch, but the atmosphere is great in the evening.  $5 to get in and then salsa dancing all night!  There's a full bar if you get thirsty and two dance floors. 

Salsa music is played and danced to--a welcome alternative to college kids bumping and grinding while sloshing cheap beer over the rims of cans.  Even if you don't know how to salsa come on by; you might meet someone who will teach you!

I will certainly try out lunch here at some point.  In the meantime, check it out on a Friday or a Saturday night!

LOVE this place, always have.  One of the few restaurants that is consistently different.  Having lived in and round C-U for waaay too long its easy to see that many places are often derivative, dull, and lack character (a good example is the bar across from RM).  I make a point of going any time i pass through town and find myself craving Radio food when I'm away for too long.

If you are looking for frisbee-sized plates full of food, look somewhere else. However, if you are looking a quality experience with an amazing staff, then Radio Maria's should be at the top of your list. Great and unique food sets them apart from the crowd. Their tapas are creative and delicious. You won't be disappointed unless you you expect or demand a ton of food. Radio is all about the flavor and passion. To me, that's much more important.

Went for brunch and would definitely recommend it.  My boyfriend and i tried the masa boat surprise, smoked pork pozole, and 2 mexican coffees.  The mexican coffee was delicious, like a spiced coffee with nutmeg, cinnamon, and clove.  My boyfriend said it had a little too much spice for him, but it reminded me of a spiced latte.  

The masa boat surprise was tasty, although I recommend getting a little bit of everything in each bite.  Eating just the egg and chorizo can be a little bland, but eating it with the veggies, cheese, salsa, black beans and some of the corn "boat" is sooo good.  

The smoked pork pozole was really good, although it could have been a dinner item if not for the poached eggs.  It was kind of like a mexican stew with a couple poached eggs, and some beer bread.  The beer bread was very tasty.  

We'll definitely be going back and try some other things.  Radio Maria's has a pretty extensive breakfast and lunch menu.

Radio Maria has been a downtown fixture for many years. I've had some tasty entrees years ago in their dining room. But their current iteration isn't quite as memorable.

There are plenty of drinks to suit many tastes. I had a mint julep (under a different fancified name) that tasted pretty standard. The late night menu is ok; nothing to rave about. We tried just about all the small plates available: tacos, pozole, and nachos. I'd rather go to a taqueria for the real deal.

Brunch is better than late night. The Bloody Mary bar is ok - just garnishes for your drink but none of the typical edible accouterments. 

The place looks lovely with its trendy, eclectic decor but the aesthetics may be deceiving. I want to like Radio Maria but my experiences here with the food and drinks have been underwhelming.

I'm saddened by the menu change. My friends and I raved about Radio Maria because of the tapas! My favorite was this garlic-lemon buttery shrimp. But this time around the menu was awful ): The food was truly disappointing. We couldn't even finish it. We asked the waiter where all the good food from the menu went and he said they changed the menu back in July. How unfortunate! Pretty much never going back.

This is one of those restaurants that makes me wish I lived in Champaign/Urbana again. Even though it's been open for years, I didn't go until recently. We went for a brunch, and the food was amazing!

My wife had the french toast and something eggy. Probably an omelet. The french toast was fabulous. I don't know what kind of bread they use, but it's perfect. She was able to taste some of the egg used, but I just tasted lovely golden syrup and cinnamon.

The cuban was served on a fresh baguette. The meat was terrific, and so was the bread. The american fries ( I think) that we each got with the meal were perfectly cooked and seasoned.

The decor is very cool, nice artwork hangs on the walls, and because it's downtown, it's close to Cowboy Monkey, The Art Theatre, and The Virginia theatre. VERY highly recommended!

The Good:
-I liked the decor.  It was very pretty.
-The "Soup of the Day" was Red Pepper-Goat Cheese.  I could eat that every single day forever and be very happy.
-Extensive beer, wine, and cocktail list.
-The boy said that his Curried Shrimp was light and pretty good.

The Bad:
-The waiter was not friendly.  He wasn't mean or bad at his job, but there was no smile.  Ever.
-The place is separated into two parts, the bar/tapas area and the 'dinner' area.  The two sides allegedly do not communicate (?).  You can't get anything from the Tapas menu in the dinner side and vice-versa.  Our suspicions were confirmed when we heard a waiter telling a customer that no, he couldn't have the "Tapa of the Day," because he didn't even know what it was.  ....What the f?  Why?!
-I had the Korean Hot Pot.  I was warned that it was spicy, which it wasn't.  It was extremely sweet.  So much so, that I had to stop eating by the time I reached the bottom layer of rice.  It was like a half cup of brown sugar had been lacquered all over the rice.  Blech!

The Ugly:
-I got food poisoning.  Thank you, Korean Hot Pot.  My guts are still kvetching about you.

...The problem is, they had so much delicious-looking stuff on the menu, that, food poisoning aside, I'll still probably go back.  If I come out unscathed next time, we'll see about upping the score.  Really, a 2 1/2 would've been perfect.

Here's the thing with Radio Maria - the food is pretty good, as is the wine selection, but the service is consistently off-putting. If you can achieve to find the hostess, she will most likely treat you like an obnoxious pest at best. Service at the table is hit or miss - I've had a couple of decent servers over the two years I've lived in Champaign, but many more ill-mannered ones who seem to regard diners as a nuisance. All in all - this could be an amazing place to spend an evening, but there are many days when the dismal service is reason enough to cut and run.

Definitely a fan of Radio Maria. It's always a safe bet for a great meal. I always have tapas but they have a full dinner menu as well. I recommend the hanger steak, plantains, and pork tacos. They also have charcuterie and cheese plate type tapas dishes that work very well as starters. The wine and beer selections are also substantially larger than the average restaurant. Anyone visiting Champaign or locals that have never been to Radio Maria should definitely give it a shot.

College town dining has changed since I went to school! Radio Maria is a hip breakfast joint in the morning and creative bar and grill at night. Great wines, appetizers with unique ingredients, and gourmet meat selections. We were pleasantly surprised the last time we were in town for a game.

I don't even know what I'm supposed to review here.  Is it a restaurant?  A tapas bar?  And what's with this sunday comfort food menu?  Do they even know anymore?

I almost feel bad giving this jack of all trades only three stars.  It's not that there's anything outright bad here:  the dining rooms are nicely decorated, the service is okay, the food is well-prepared, the wine and beer selection is thorough but not amazing.  You probably won't be disappointed.

But then there's nothing about this place that's outright great, either.

Radio Maria was the first restaurant downtown, and they did a fabulous job.  But now the dinner menu hasn't changed in years, they got rid of a lot of their good lunch menu (in favor of tapas), and they've got this strange "upscale comfort food" menu on Sundays that doesn't seem to fit in very well.

Even the service - which used to be their highest point - has been slipping.  As the old guard moves on, they're being replaced with awkward servers who don't know (and don't seem to care) about the food and drinks they're serving.

I will, inevitably, go back.  But since I can go just a few doors down, spend a few more dollars and get an exceptional meal, why wouldn't I?

I used to love this place. The food is a bit pricey for the amount you get, but it was always delicious. I believe that they must have changed chefs sometime in the past year because there was a marked difference in the food not too long ago and it was a disappointment. The portions got smaller and far more careless in the preparation and presentation.

Came here for tapas with my mom and brother on a Sunday night. We ordered 7 tapas to split between us. The service was slow and a bit... ditsy... 

A couple items we ordered didn't exactly match the description on the menu... For example: the Eggplant Frites had no balsamic vinegar... 

Our artisanal cheeses were served with tiny hard pieces of pita bread, weird.

When we received the "warm bread it with butter" tapa, we got the some boring and COLD pita bread that was served with the cheese. Beyond that, they gave us about 15x the amount of butter that could fit on the pita they served us. The waitress who served the tapas explained the types of butter, but after trying them we realized she didn't actually know what she was serving because she clearly described the wrong flavors. 

Back to the cold pita that was served... When the waitress finally returned, I asked if she could have the pita warmed, after all, the tapa is called "warm" bread and butter, right? When she brought the pita back, it had been deep fried.. WHAT? When we talked to the waitress about our disappointment she seemed flustered and then admit to us that she agreed it was weird to serve pita with the cheese but they were out of the crackers (we weren't even referring to the how weird it was to get pita with the cheese plate at this point) and then she continued to ask us if we wanted her to serve the bread that was supposed to come with the bread and butter... She then brought us out some cold, but real bread. Still not sure why this wasn't served in the first place...

In summary:
Service: Terrible 
Food: Pretty good, despite the fee makes that chef made 
Atmosphere: Very nice! You can choose to sit in a casual area or a dining room
Prices: Pretty expensive for the amount of food you're getting

This place is pretty awesome in downtown Champaign.  I had the torta maria out of sheer curiosity for what sweet potatoes, goat cheese, tortillas, and vanilla bean sauce tasted like all together.  Goodness me!  That's some good stuff to put on your fork!

We usually sit at the bar and order up tapas and drinks.  The bartender never missed a  chance to mix us up a mean cocktail of his own creation.  The food is good and priced right.  The atmosphere is also wonderful, and very unique.  They also serve brunch, which is great!

Love the decor and the ambiance of this place, people  working there are great, really fun  business casual look and really polite service. Lounge part of the restaurant is relaxed and fun.
Food is great, loved the variety of tapas and the uniqueness of regular menu, between two we ate like 6 tapas and shared a coffee steak total like $70.

Came here one evening for tapas with friends. I was the only one that ordered for the four of us and our waiter just starred at us for awhile asking if we were sure that's all we wanted. You could tell he hadn't been working there long as he had to ask the kitchen twice about what was in some of the different sauces and I had to repeat my order twice so that he could remember it. 

I ordered the Wild Mushroom Crostini, Smoked Pork Tacos and Sauteed Calamari. My favorite was the Wild Mushroom Crostini. The mixture of the cheese, fried egg and mushrooms with the crunch of the bread made it delicious. The Sauteed Calamari was an interesting dish with a lot of flavor. It came out in a soup dish so it was great to dip just some of the bread in the sauce. The Pork Tacos were my least favorite as there was too much green onion for my liking.

The food was good but each dish was made for two people rather than four. As we were finishing our plates, a waitress cleaned our table without asking if we were done, which peeved me because I wasn't done with the calamari.

David S. and I were here for  brunch today, and it was pretty sweet! They had a variety of options, and a full bar and a commendable wine list. We started with bloody marys though I was tempted to try the bloody maria. My goat cheese, trout and avocado omelet was fresh and delicious and David seemed happy with his tuna, so we made one happy brunching family! Though, can I just say, his tuna was his hunk of meat that looked like a rarely done steak, it was massive. Our waitress was very nice and checked in on us very frequently. All in all, a great brunch experience, I would definitely come back here!

Went here for brunch a couple times and dinner once and had overall positive experiences. 

First time, my girlfriend ordered mango juice and Cinnabon pancakes. The mango juice was simply awesome, very fresh. The pancakes were equally tasty, warm, soft, and just the right amount of cream. 

I ordered the masa boat surprise, which was basically a large assortment of scrambled eggs, chorizo, beans, and vegetables with a cornmeal "boat." This boat was an absolutely mouthwatering crispy, cheesy biscuit and to me was the highlight of the dish. It came with tortillas too so you can make a couple breakfast tacos within the meal. 

We both split a side of house potatoes and unfortunately they were noticeably over salted, essentially impossible to eat. We told the waiter and he assured us they would cook a fresh batch. Unfortunately the new batch had 0 salt on it, so this was either a misunderstanding, misguided nice gesture, or intentionally unsympathetic. Either way, we salted it ourselves and added hot sauce in order to be able to eat it. They were quite crispy and fresh otherwise. 

Our waiter was very attentive and great. I had my coffee refilled throughout the entire meal, which was much appreciated. 

The second time, I ordered the Lloyd's omelet, which had smoked trout, cream cheese, and avocado. It was awesome and very filling. My girlfriend had a fruit bowl, which was alright but the waiter snatched it before she was done eating without asking. So that was weird. 

Overall, I had a positive time both visits and would recommend going for brunch if you haven't already. There aren't many other places with CU that do legitimate brunches with so many options like Radio Maria.

As for dinner, I ordered the paella and it was delicious, but way too pricy in my opinion. The service was fine and I really enjoyed the bottomless $15 mimosa deal, which offered orange, strawberry, grapefruit, pineapple, mango, guava, peach, and pear.

Food was decent - the Radio Maria torta was the best thing we tried. The tacos didn't hold a candle to L.A. or Portland taco trucks (the arepa was good but not the best I've had). We also had the tapas special which was steak with bacon-wrapped avocado - the steak was quite good, and the idea of the avocado was interesting. Desserts here were quite tasty.
The drinks were okay - enough alcohol to know there was some in the drink, but they were mixed towards the bitter side rather than sweet.
The service was incredibly slow. It took at least an hour to get our food. Biggest complaint of the night, and makes me not inclined to return.

What can I say? Having studied abroad in southern Spain for a semester in college, Radio Maria's Spanish flare and tapas menu really pluck at a heartstring with me. I love enjoying late afternoon tapas on a warm summer day with great drinks and better friends. 

I'm not forgetting the great selection of entrees this restaurant/bar offers, but in typical Spanish fashion, I usually fill up on beer and tapas before I can even contemplate dinner. While they don't serve dinner all night long, they do continue serving their most popular tapas until close. 

So grab a group of friends and head over to Radio Maria soon; the availability of food at all hours makes it a great place to start or end a night downtown!

I enjoyed the atmosphere and the selection on the menu, as it offers food you cant really find anywhere else in the C-U.  I thought the menu items were decently priced, maybe a bit overpriced for the quantity and quality of the food.  

I ordered three tapas dishes - the grilled plantains, the goat cheese, and the beef tacos.  The goat cheese was fried and served with honey and bread and it was absolutely delicious!  The plantains were pretty plain, but still a nice change of pace from what I normally eat day to day.  The beef tacos were tasty, but they were incredibly hard to eat when served in dry corn shelled tortillas.  They cracked and fell apart so it was a bit frustrating to end up having to eat a taco with a fork.  

Our service was absolutely terrible, I had to flag down the host at one point to get my water glass refilled, and she brought out all of our food at different times which was a bit strange.  

Overall, I was happy with the food I ordered and how it was prepared and how it tasted - were talking about Champaign, Illinois, not Chicago or New York - and unhappy with the service.  I wouldn't tell someone not to go there, because it is a unique restaurant for this area, but I would be warned that the service will likely be disappointing.

My husband and I recently ate at Radio Maria for dinner.  We'd had Sunday brunch and loved it at that time.  In all fairness, it started out wrong.  The employee seating us went to get us a table and was sidetracked by another employee at the entrance to the dining room and let us wait for at least 7 min. while he carried on an obvious flirtation/personal conversation with the other employee.  He finally looked away and saw us standing at the front door and that reminded him that we were still waiting.  I'm a relatively patient person but I was considering walking out at eating next door at Bacaro at that point - not because the wait was so long, but because we were so easily forgotten from the get go.  It was rude.The best I can say is that the dinner service left a lot to be desired (our waitress was tired and stressed) and the accoustics of the restaurant are such that larger tables are extremely loud, making it difficult to carry on a conversation in a normal voice.  The food was marginal at best although you have to give them points for creativity.  Wasn't a pleasant experience and my husband became very ill later that evening and lost his meal.  I wouldn't recommend it for dinnertime but may try again for brunch.

This place rocks!

The local art and industrial found object decor is so unique and interesting.

The food is fantastic. If tapas isn't your thing, check them out for brunch. The posole is to die for! Their poached eggs are perfect. Don't eden get me started on the griddles beer bread. If you do join for dinner, the extensive beer and wine lists will ensure your entree is never left unpaired. 

Service has been great for me.


Seriously though, this place was probably so groundbreaking when they opened 20 years ago. Whenever I sit in the bar area, I feel like I'm entering some exclusive club.
Simply put, this is one of the best "date places" in Champaign.  The food is amazing and priced very well.  The bar is a blast and the staff is very friendly.
Lots of great tapas selections.  Go with a group and share the many things on the menu.  The regular dinners are good too but the tapas is definitely where it's at.

We went there for dinner and heard that the tapas plates weren't worth the money so we went with full sized entrees. Every dish was delicious and the flavors are surprisingly good for being in a small town. They have an array of holiday drinks that weren't bad. Pricey for being on a college student budget but delicious nonetheless

The atmosphere and food are both 5 stars.  Our party of three was seated by the windows which was nice.  We shared a few bottles of wine recommend by our server, Jean Luc.  We enjoyed the scallops, hangar steak, and pork chops.  Everything was cooked perfectly. It was a lovely evening of wine, food and conversation.  We will be back!

Typically love this place but today they were very rude and forced us to sit at the bar while there are 8 empty tables around us. They claimed it was because of reservations but as we left, those same tables were still empty. Bartender was rude and short with all answers and told us we had to wait to put in orders and just because we sat at the bar doesn't mean we don't have to wait before other guests. And he kept yelling at the new bartender who was very sweet to us.

Food was entirely edible, and arrived promptly. That's the end of my praise. 

Not once did a member of the staff smile at us. In fact, when we walked through the door, two hosts (or perhaps a host and a server) bickered quietly about who had to seat us.

I started out by ordering a French 75 from their special drinks menu, which didn't arrive until after we ordered food. The drink was absolutely horrible, and tasted like it was half bottled lemon juice. When I complained and started to ask for maybe a gin and tonic to replace it (which should be a cheaper drink if anything), our waiter whisked it away and said "I'll fix it." No apology, or opportunity to tell him what I wanted. The second drink included real lemon juice and the green heel of a lemon, but this time I could taste the stale wine they were trying to cover up. I later learned they don't measure any of their drinks.

The food was fine. The menu was a mix of everything Spanish and Latin American, which was surprising considering they call it all tapas, but we gave it a shot. Our salad was wilted, and the dressing tasted bottled, so it was not worth the money at all. We ordered potatoes with tomato, and it came out with sweet, clearly jarred, pasta sauce and finely grated cheese. (Does the Midwest want everything to be pizza?) We also had plantains, which were the highlight but still nothing to write home about, and a shrimp dish that was very bland aside from a lot of salt.

After dinner, we went to V. Picasso for wine and dessert, and had an incredible experience for admittedly close to the same price. We only spent $45 at Radio Maria, but it was much more than the restaurant deserved. Won't be returning.

Visited this restaurant for the first time with my girlfriend due to friend recommendation. And I have to say, it does live up to the hype. 

Since it was early in the morning on a weekend, we liked to start out our meal with some nice coffee. Not gonna lie, if you are looking to some authentic Mexican coffee, save it. Their coffee was not their highlight. 

They offered two specials that day: an omelette and a stuffed chili pepper. We listened to our friendly waiter's recommendation and ordered one of each. 

Their baked potatoes that accompanied the core of the meals were phenomenal! The temperature was perfectly controlled and all the pieces of the potatoes were cooked evenly, and just right. Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, with just the right amount of salt to make it appeal to the tongues. 

It is very hard for me to describe the main courses in details, since there was a lot going on, but just know that food is served in a timely fashion, and the impact of the flavors truly made the visit an overall enjoyable experience. Definitely keep a lookout on the specials if you want something more memorable. 

 The restaurant itself is very clean, and was decorated with interesting Hispanic things that created an unique atmosphere that made it ideal for 1 on 1 dining. Definitely would return to this place next time I am in town.

I am giving this restaurant 0 stars.  
I don't want anyone else wasting their money at this establishment. Here goes:

My fellow students and I had organized a fundraiser to be held at R.M. We were raffling off some of our artwork and had ordered a substantial amount of food because we were expecting 50+ guests. Around 8:30pm, there was an AWFUL stench that filled the bar area, followed by a watery mist that began to fall from the ceiling along the west wall of tables. There were a number of people sitting in this area (myself included), who were covered in this putrid water (I had to go home and shower!!!). The food we ordered which was on a nearby table, was also covered. I alerted the manager who said to me "It must be our pipes again." Again? This has happened to other customers? The manager then called the fire department in to inspect the pipes running along the ceiling, while our guests (those who were left) crowded awkwardly around the bar.  

The manager took no action in remedying the situation. Our food was NOT replaced, and the water on the tables and chairs was NOT wiped up, so that the guests could resume sitting. The artwork that was hanging on the wall was also damaged by the water, and was NOT compensated for. Radio Maria had quoted us for the cost of food prior to the event, but when we received our bill, it was over twice what they had quoted. Worse yet, the manager only refunded us the cost of one cheese plate. Thanks. You're swell.  This matter is still not resolved as the owners of Radio Maria seem to think they owe us nothing. I disagree, and until we receive just compensation, I will not be returning and hope you don't either.

Two words. Grilled plaintains. HO MY GOD.

No, but really, the couple times I've been here have been good. Normally, I've only come for drinks but today was the second time I've come for food. 

The tapas are a little on the expensive side (they are tapas after all I guess) but I think they're very tasty. In a perfect world, I'd like to have maybe 4 arancini for 5 bucks, but it is what it is. Unless you're ballin' out of control, you're not going to eat here everyday. Living on grad assistant paychecks, it's a nice treat to come here.

I really can't speak to any of the problems that folks have had with service, etc. My group today came in and the servers set up a nice big table for us. They also brought out some carafes for water which is something restaurants tend not to do.

Anyway, 4 stars. Take your date here. He/she will thank you.

What a unique, wonderful place!  This place has 2 sides, each with their own menu: a tapas side and a restaurant side, I ate in the tapas side.  Must have = eggplant frites.  Their drink menu was extensive, but pricey.  The service was a little slow, but granted, it was a Saturday night.  The server was personable and ready to provide recommendations though.  The place itself is beautiful and modern, and they decorate with art from local artists.  I'd definitely go back when I visit Champaign.
Love this place! Amazing food, I would recommend the pesto omelette!! If you go there at night you've got to try a beer that you have never had. Love the selection and proves are reasonable.

We came here and had the sautéed mushrooms, stewed oxtail, lamb meatballs, steamed mussels, sautéed calamari, patatas, roasted tomato and shrimp crostini, and crispy bone marrow. The mushrooms were bland -- the broth needs to be more flavorful. The bone marrow was also disappointing, the sauces on the plate did not complement the bone marrow at all. The crostini was very average, too much bread and oversized tomatoes for the amount of shrimp rendered.

On the other hand, the stewed oxtail was absolutely delicious -- the meat was tender and the broth full of umami flavor. I was also a big fan of the lamb meatballs, perfectly done with a creative sauce to match. The potatoes were well seasoned and the dressing paired nicely. The mussels were served in generous proportion.

Overall, 50/50 good bad. This was my second visit and I definitely trust Radio Maria for a night out dining.

Ate here for the first time last Friday night with a friend. The atmosphere was pretty relaxed and mellow. I ordered a pollo plato, and I thought it was tasty, especially in how the sauces complemented the noodles and the chicken. However it did cost $24 before taxes and tips. I also tried the featured cocktail, the raspberry-lime rickey. I thought it was a miss; it was too watery.

Radio Maria is a great restaurant for a chill dinner or a romantic date. They also have a bar section that I have yet to explore. I've heard good things about their paellas and tapas, and I think I'll come back in sometime soon to try them out.

This place was wonderful!! There were only two of us at 4:30 on a Monday afternoon.  We got seated promptly in the dining room.  The host stated it was the best place to sit if we were wanting to talk.

Our waiter was amazing and very knowledgeable.  He was able to answer all of our wine and food questions.  
We started with some glasses of wine.  I had the Riesling and it did not disappoint.  My aunt had the Malbec and said it was great.  I finished the evening with Quinta de Aveleda Vinho Verde and I regret not getting this first.  This wine may be a new favorite.

We decided to order a few different plates.  I ordered the humus and atun.  Both were amazing!!  The humus was very smooth and rich and the pita that it comes with was out of this world.  I don't think a description of the atun would do it justice.  It was just wonderful.  Very flavorful and the pickled cucumbers and spicy guacamole it was served with was a great pairing. 
My aunt ordered the hongos and camaron.  I do not like mushrooms but I thought I would try the hongos.  I loved them.  I don't know what they did to them, but the sauce they are served with really compliments it well. The camaron had a nice little kick to it, not spicy just a nice kick. 

Overall I had a wonderful experience for my first time here.  I would highly recommend trying this place out.  I will certainly be back.

Nice restaurant in downtown Champaign.  Has a really nice atmosphere.  Good selection of wines.  I really wanted to like this place but in the end, their food is just forgettable.  I had the lamb once and that was a bit rough, not tender.  Also tried the salmon (or some other fish) once, also a bit overcooked.  Dessert menu was very standard.

On a recent trip to Chambana my family stopped here to celebrate my sister's graduation from UIUC and were quite pleased.  To start, the wine list was decent with selections from the west coast to Burgundy and Bordeaux, though they were slightly more marked up that I've been used to in Chicago.  However, the kitchen was very clearly overextended on the graduation Saturday.  While I don't fault them for that I must comment that it didn't seem like they had tried to shove extra tables into the restaurant so it shouldn't have taken 3 hours for dinner, especially since we ordered quite quickly after we were seated.

As for the food, we started with the arancini and garlic shrimp skewers.  The arancini was satisfying though plain, and the shrimp skewers were well done.  The entrees were bold options that suffered only slightly from less than perfect execution and definitely warrant a return trip.  I enjoyed the pan roasted duck with goat cheese polenta and roasted beets, while my family selected their daily special (a salmon dish) or the hangar steak topped with bacon and a fried egg.  

As I mentioned, the entrees were good enough to warrant a return trip.  Hopefully on my next trip to Chambana the kitchen will be less burdened and I'll be able to enjoy my meal at a slightly less leisurely pace.

did lunch in their new tapas bar today.  had to sit at a bar table with those dreadful high chairs because there were no booths available. i'm not a big fan of being uncomfortable...ever.
our waiter was great, in fact he added to my experience.  the interior is very well done for that particular genre.
