the food, eh, nothing to write home about.  had a small salad with the standard blue cheese, grapes, apples, walnuts=better than average.  then shared a few tapas with my friend.  we had the pita triangles with hummus and the tuna salad sandwich.  the portions were acurately small.  flavor was good but again, nothing special.  it was extremely cheap though...in addition to the food above we had the blackberry iced tea and 2 coffees and each spent $12 including tip.

Eh.  I have some issues with this place.  It has really good potential but I definitely have mood swings about it.  The main restaurant is decent.  The food isn't necessarily anything I couldn't make myself but it is good, especially for me-- a vegetarian, who has had trouble finding interesting vegetarian food at many of the places in CU.  Also, the wine selection is pretty decent.  BUT, I think the tapas side is just terrible.  We've only eaten in that part one time and I believe it was a Tuesday night, but essentially every dish we got had something wrong with it.  The biggest issue was that we were served the Spanish tortilla omelet refrigerator cold.  It is supposed to be GRILLED.  Not grilled then put in the fridge over the weekend!  We told our server and she told us that was how it was supposed to be.  Alrighty then!  Actually, every tapas we ordered was COLD, but this was the one that stood out the most (who wants cold eggs?  Not me!!).

Maybe I need to experience the brunch to give a fair assessment, but for now I'm giving 2 stars (4 for the restaurant + 1 for tapas)/2 = 2 when rounding down).

Every time the convo about restaurants in Champaign starts, the mom-in-law mentions Radio Maria. Her praise hits often and reaches far. Tonight, we finally had dinner at the infamous Champaign culinary sensation.

The food offering was a mish-mash of cuisines - South American, Asian, Mediterranean, Spanish - and seemed to lack a consistent and unifying theme/thread/philosophy. These types of menus are generally red flags for me because they say: I can do a breadth of styles good, but not one style great.

We started off sharing the mezze plate. Pita was pizza dough-y, but buttery too...strange, in my opinion. Also, I found the couscous bland. Best part was the hummus, which I was wishing they served more of.

For dinner I ordered the crabcakes, which were more like crabballs. Goat cheese potato pancakes were crisp, but lacked seasoning. Radio Maria's Haitian slaw was flavorless and served merely as decoration on my plate - I hate to say it, but KFC's got better slaw! Positives about the crabballs - they weren't THAT bad and you get three in an order. If you order this, ask for extra garlic aioli (probably best to ask for it on the side). I probably would've enjoyed my balls (but, really...who doesn't?!) more if I had extra aioli.

Beau ordered the adobo pork. Generous hunk of pig, the orange-bourbon BBQ sauce starts sweet on the tongue, then finishes with a kick...flavor was decent, but I wasn't expecting or enjoying this sweet sweet meat (SHOCK, I know!). Jalapeno-cheddar cornbread was interesting in concept, but lacking in execution...I would've never known there was jalapeno unless the menu told me! Like the roughage on my plate, the honey left his chayote-cilantro salad be.

Call me crazy, but I AM willing to try their brunch and/or tapas, but lemme check-in with not-my-bio-mama first...

Food is definitely a 4.  Friends and I ordered a bunch of tapa dishes to share.  The potatoes were good.  The lamb meatballs were average, a bit on the dry side.  The chorizo and potatoes with fried egg was tasty but also so bad.  I would recommend just picking one of the potato dishes.  The hanger steak was really good.  I could have eaten several orders of this alone and nothing else.  It was cooked just right and very tender.  The cheese and charcuterie plate were very good.  I would definitely recommend these 2 plates if you want something light and to share with friends.  Definitely worth it for the tapas but it adds up with each plate going between $8 to $12. The downside is the service is not up to par for how good the food is.  Service is a little slow like some other reviews have mentioned.  Would I eat here again? Definitely yes.

Looking for an omelet using my Yelp Mobile application I ended up at Radio Maria. I was hoping Sam's Cafe was open with a more diverse breakfast menu, but to no avail, I would head to the trendy (read: odd) Radio Maria. Not Maria's Radio, because who has a radio now a days? I don't even have an Pod so I am one to talk about technological advances.

We were seated on a Saturday afternoon during the beginning of Restaurant Week in Champaign. They were setting up all along the street for a big festival, so I figured we should get somewhere quick before all the drunks show up...haha. There is a dining room (which is where we were) and a bar/tapas area. Seems really trendy, hipster, and urbanized. You're definitely not in the suburbs of Chicago anymore!

I went with the Greek omelet that comes with house potatoes and beer bread, to which I got fruit instead of the potatoes. I also got a grilled plantain. That's a banana (almost, different genus species for all you biology nerds out there).

Total for two people was under $20. Waitress was great refilling my water, but she had too much lipstick on and didn't really seemed pleased to see me, which was disappointing because most people love to see a short, quirky, medium skinned Yelp Elite member. Not Ashley, who was our server. Oh well. Will I go back? Probably not, but this makes the grade. I used that pun because I am a teacher who teaches things to people...hahaha.

TURN DOWN THE DAMN RADIO, MARIA.

This is our go-to date night dinner out. I have never had a problem getting a gluten free meal here.  I'd give it a 4.5 star rating if I could!

I haven't been disappointed with a meal- we've tried the coffee crusted fillet, scallops, hanger steak, duck breast, ahi tuna and a few other specials! Always just the perfect amount and gluten free! 

One complaint is that the menu is rarely updated. The last time we went they added an acorn squash risotto to the appetizer list and it was fabulous but new items are super rare.

I've been here for both brunch and dinner. Dinner was mediocre at best, but I enjoy their brunch. It is likely the best brunch in Champaign-Urbana. The french toast is a huge serving and delicious. The omelettes are nice as well. To avoid a long wait on the weekends, I would recommend getting there at around 10:30 a.m.

I went here for dinner, and was really impressed. The evening atmosphere is really nice, I got there around 9 and there were candles on the tables. The server was super nice and attentive, my water glass was full the whole night. He answere dall our questions about sizes of dishes as well.

I got the Briar Patch cocktail which was really good, and looked pretty. Very fruity with nice quality alcohol. I got the VIeras which are seared scallops on risotto cake with whipped goat cheese and arugula. I got the portion with 2 scallops which was SO filling! The scallops were perfectly seared and not chewy at all and the whipped goat cheese is a game changer, so good. 

My friend got the paella negra, which comes in a good portion. It isn't incredibly spiced, but the squid ink is really rich. There is also a really good amount of seafood (shrimp, a nice scallop, squid) and well cooked rice. Overall really pleasant dining experience!

Awesome atmosphere, creative and very well prepared food, excellent wines and beers, and great service. The space is very well done in a mix of old Champaign with some more subtle modern features. 

Ate here on a visit from Seattle and was very impressed. My steak was one of the tastiest, most tender cuts I've had anywhere (including any upscale steak house). The gnocchi was outstanding. The prawns with the bacon, amazing.

I didn't think Champaign had cool restaurants with awesome food...was I ever wrong!

Very disappointed. Went with husband to celebrate his 40th birthday because so many local people had recommended it.

Great:
Cocktails and decor. Food, except for the nacho chips.

Bad:
Crushed nacho chips served with the queso. C'mon, not at this price point.
Sticky champagne glass in which my French 75 was served.
Everything about the service was disjointed, unorganized, unresponsive. Pacing was WAY off. We'd go between the server showing up every 30 seconds to not seeing her for 30 minutes. We always had an order in the kitchen. There were 2 or 3 tables seated, max. What was up with the kitchen that night? It was Saturday.
I kept getting the drink menu that was missing the first page.
Received excuse after excuse about the kitchen. After a while, these apologies ring empty.

It's outrageous that this restaurant sits nearly empty on a Saturday night when so many other restaurants within a half mile serving bar-n-grill garbage are bursting at the seams.

Get it together, Maria, I really wanted to like your restaurant.

We've always liked Radio and they do have an excellent beer selection. However, they appear to have grown tired. their menu seldom changes, has few really exciting options, and perhaps most unforgivably, they appear to be catering to the bland Midwest palate. They used to have truly interesting foods with abundant flavor. they also seem to experience an inordinate turnover in their staff. we went there last night and had some of the worst service ever. it took almost 3 hours for appetizers, entrée and desert. seldom saw our waiter. very frustrating experience. I sincerely hope they pick it back up as I can remember when it was a really good place to eat. But at least, they have that excellent beer selection....

I come here for business every so often, usually on weeknights. Last weekend My wife and I decided to go for a date. We were seated promptly, and the restaurant was not full, but it was clear that there were some staffing issues and it took a long time to even get a glass of water. The waiter was doing his best - he is professional and I have had him before - but it was clear that there were insufficient staff working. 

We ordered tapas, which are deliciously prepared and large in portion size. However, when we ordered the hummus, there was too much to be possibly consumed with the pita chips that were provided. We asked for more, and got a somewhat strange response, "well that will be another 50 cents!"  Somehow either they need to be free (I mean, come on) or make them a couple of bucks, or raise the price on the dish. 

Anyway, after a long wait for dinner and dessert and the check we were out in nearly 3 hours. I like romantic dinners, but the babysitter bill was a bit high for the date.

My friend and I came in around noon on a Sunday, there was quite the wait for a table but bar seats available immediately so we took them up on that! Service was pretty slow but considering it was Easter Sunday we were understanding.

I got the Biscuits and Gravy, which took around half an hour to come out. I got my eggs scrambled and they were super bland. The gravy was good though, so that made eating them a little easier. Biscuits were a little hard and too floury. I would probably get a different dish next time if I'm ever back. My friend got the Eggs Benedict with pulled pork and agreed on it being a little bland as well. 

PS they have $15 bottomless mimosas on Sundays!

Didn't actually had a proper meal here. Just ordered tacos under tapa on the menu. I didn't like the taco shells. The flavor was okay, just pretty standard. I also ordered Hibiscus Mojito. That was very good.

Once upon a time this place was good... but I can't say that's true any longer.  I believe that the tapas area is a good bar.. but not so much a good restaurant.  Go to Cafe Luna for better and cheaper food.  

I used to enjoy the other restaurant.  They still have good free chips and salsa (that you eat while you wait for your food).  The actual stuff on the menu is not so good.  Also.. they haven't changed the menu in the last half year.  Everything on it right now seems Spanish inspired.. and some of the things aren't so inspiring to eat.

UPDATE: I went here for drinks the other night.  I am not a big fan of their table set up even though the bar was pretty cool.  I think they must not have very good bartender's working here on the weekend.  It took like five minutes for them to figure out how to make a rum and diet Coke.  And it didn't even taste right!  It was like vanilla rum or vanilla Coke.  But to their credit, I heard they have good mojitos.

The food here is good but the portions are miniscule, and I don't mean the tapas, and the prices are outrageous for what they are serving. I actually left here hungry after getting a monkey bread appetizer, a tuna dinner dish, a drink and a dessert. The check arrived and I felt disheartened by the total which was 70$+ for two still very hungry people with the worst part being that I rarely complain about the smallness of food portions, the are usually too big in fact, but this was not the case here.

This is the WORST service I've ever experienced in my LIFE. Will be calling to speak with the manager tomorrow!

UPDATE: I was kicked out and the bar was shut down completely for asking to speak to a manager about bad customer service. There was no aggression or any violent or inappropriate language/behavior being used on our behalf. We were told by one of the managers "I don't have time for you" and "talking to you is stopping me from helping the people at the other end of the bar" (which was the problem in the first place, because they were only serving half of the bar). Since speaking to a "manager" did not suffice, I will be going into the establishment on Monday and asking for the owner or their contact information to make them aware of how their employees are treating PAYING customers. We were IGNORED, then DISRESPECTED, and proceeded to be kicked out. I was there trying to celebrate my college graduation, just to be treated like less then a person. They will never receive another dime from me!
A grad school fav... This place has stood the test of time, which is the best indication of restaurant quality.

Please, Radio Maria owners, read these reviews and take corrective action! Do not rest on your laurels because that way failure lies...

I don't get to go to Radio Maria as often as I used to. It has a fond place in my heart, which is probably good for them as I'm not dinging them as much as I could in this review. RM was one of the first hip businesses that launched the downtown revival (along with The Blind Pig, v 1.0) and for that I have much love.

The last few times we've gone, we've sat outside and had tapas. Now I'm no tapas expert, but I believe you usually order a bunch of tapas and they come out one-at-a-time to your table so you can experience each dish on its own merits.  RM, however, always sends out all the tapas all at the same time. Everything becomes a mish-mash and it's overwhelming and nothing stands out.  You also immediately get abandoned by the waitstaff so you have to wait forever to order another drink or get/pay your check. 

Also, the pretty pretty people who work there don't like kids. That would be fair if we were dragging the kids inside and interrupting the restaurant. But even if your kids are well-behaved and you're sitting outside, you catch a real snotty attitude. I am happy to report, however, that they do have a real highchair. When my eldest was a baby they had a beautiful vintage deathtrap highchair. They now have one that is still aesthetically pleasing, but without all the metal.

The restaurant itself is still lovely. I just wish they'd shape up their staff so it wasn't so depressing to interact with them.

Great food! Very flavorful. Recommend trying the camarón (shrimp), queso fundido (cheese dip with chorizo), and arrozito frito (fried risotto cakes)! 

Tapas are small, so if you order for a group, about 2 tapas per person is a good starting point! 

Only complaint is that we waited pretty long for our food (~45 minutes).

Just felt like adding the fact that I have traveld extensively through all of southern Spain and am very familiar with tapas. The food at this place does not remotely resemble anything I have had in Spain or any other good tapas restaurants in the US (New York, DC, SF, etc.). Everything lacks in flavor and freshness. Bottom line, hate it.

We decided to check out brunch. It had good reviews and we wanted something different. Not that impressed. The host argued with us when we said we would like to be seated inside. It was a nice day but the tables that were left outside were all in direct sunlight and we didn't bring sunglasses or a hat. We were sat and ordered an OJ( it was not good) and coffee. I ordered the regular eggs Benedict. The ham and the sauce were great,the eggs had no real flavor which is fine but they were not cooked all the way. When I cut into the egg,the white under cooked part came out with the yolk. My husband had the scramble and said it was ok but not memorable. Overall if some friends asked us to go we would go again but would never choose to come back on our own.

I dearly loved this place when I lived in C-U. Never had a bad meal, although sometimes it was marred with indifferent service of the "I am a hipster working in the hippest restaurant in town! What, you want me to DO WORK?" type. 

Brunch was awesome; a lot cheaper than dinner so my impoverished self could get a fix when mom and dad weren't paying. The beer bread, yes, and the masa boat, yes! And at the time they opened, renovating a decrepit downtown location to expose the brick walls and original tin ceilings was a new idea. They kickstarted a great trend. Downtown Champaign wouldn't be what it is today without Radio Maria. I remember going to that space to pick out wallpaper with my mom and dad back in the 80's. Radio Maria is a vast improvement.

I used to go [almost] every Sunday for brunch. 
Phenomenal. 
I still crave the beer bread. and the Masa boat

The interior is so artfully done. I always found myself staring at the sculptural objects on the walls. And the tables made with old doors. Very cool. 

(Sadly, I could never afford a real dinner experience here on my student budget.)

I had Sunday brunch here. The atmosphere is cool. I like the decor and atmosphere. The server brought me a water right away. Took our drink order and they came out kind of promptly. My drink was fine but my friend's mimosa had barely any champagne in it. After our server took our order the staff was pretty good about refilling waters and coffee. The second round of drinks took quite some time to come out. 

After about 20 minutes we were told our ticket never made it to the kitchen and they were working on it. During this time I saw another table approach a server and say "is our food coming? We have been waiting for 45 minutes. If not we have to leave." The server assured him it was on the way. 

At this point it had been 20 more minutes and my water had stopped being refilled. I went to ask for a manger and the hostess told me she could handle it. I explained how long our food was taking and maybe we could have a round of drinks or dessert on the house. She assured me we would be taken care of and that they were "really busy." It was an average busy day. 

10 minutes later our food came out with the exception of my plate. Which arrived 10 minutes later. At this time I saw the gentleman from the other table approach his server again and say "we are leaving this is ridiculous." And he walked out with his group. There were several empty tables at this point. Someone came to our table but didn't identify themselves as a manger or anything. Gave us a really half hearted apology and said they would take $3 off or a beverage off each of our checks. He seemed annoyed and said "we are busy and restaurants make mistakes." Uhhhh okay. 

The food was pretty good. My steak was a bit over cooked but the potatoes were delicious. The eggs were not good at all. A few people at my table had incorrect orders but didn't want to waste more time sending them back. 

When our checks were brought out they gave them to the wrong people, most of the checks were incorrect and some didn't have the mentioned discount. So we had to wait for them to be fixed. 

Overall not a great experience, won't be back. We are a group that brunches in the area often and have already told our large networking group to avoid this spot. Good service is so much more important than good food.

I came here for brunch on a Sunday morning. The wait wasn't too bad for two people close to noon. There are tons of delicious sounding options on their breakfast menu, especially the benedicts, but I finally settled on the radio scrambler because it seemed to be a little of everything. No complaints here--the scrambler was loaded with eggs, cheese, potatoes, bacon, and gravy, all piled on some beer bread. By the way, the beer bread is fantastic! Overall, it was a great meal and I hope to be back again for brunch or tapas.

A very interesting spot in downtown Champaign.  A tapas bar, beer bar, brunch spot on the weekends, cocktail bar, and what else?  I am probably missing something...

Tables spread out up front.  A blue lit bar, and a spinning wheel of taps.  Strange lighting, and can get very loud later at night.  Artsy and hip without being completely pretentious.  Just a little though.

Service can be a bit slow, but always friendly and knowledgeable.  Beer list is always rotating.  Founders, Dark Horse, Ballast Point, plenty of other US micros and a good selection of imports.  I think the wheel has about 30 taps.  Then a creative cocktail menu, which I have yet to try.  Outside of Blind Pig, this was one of the first true beer bars in the area.

Food is interesting.  A mix of tapas, other small plates, and brunch.  Hanger Steak is good, as is the duck.  Not everything is a hit, but there is enough good stuff to keep you coming back.  Like bone marrow, pork shoulder, and ricotta.  

This is definitely a place to check out downtown.  An interesting mix of different bar and restaurant concepts.  Good beer, interesting and often very good food.  Good spot.
A gem in Champaign! If you love Spanish cuisine then give this place a try! My favorite restaurant to date!

Nothing at this restaurant warrants the cost. The tapas servings are tiny (for tapas); brunch is inventive but disappoints. The staff always act like you're wasting their time. This place sells an image of Euro-trendiness, but it's nothing more than that image. Go to Escobar if you want expensive food WORTH the cost.

Great Tapas. I want to go back for more. Wish they had better hours though. 

The parking lot attendant was rude. Couldn't wait in my car to wait for my friend to arrive. Made me not want to go into the restaurant, so I didn't. They're so worried someone might park there that isn't going to Radio Marias.

I came here for tapas after reading the reviews on yelp.  I love to eat tapas in my hometown and was a little skeptical whether or not this place could live up to my LA expectations.  Radio Maria did not disappoint!

First off, I loved the atmosphere.  The architecture and style of the place is so artistic and unique.  It's beautiful.  I love the artwork all over the walls and the bar area especially.  

The dim lighting and the small bites menu definitely makes it a great place to go out with friends or to go on a date.  The drinks are reasonably priced and tasty too.

I had the lamb meatballs, the bread with fig jam,  and the bread with serrano pork and orange marmalade and the potatoes.  I'm forgetting the name of each dish but they are on the tapas menu. Everything I ordered was great, but the potatoes were AMAZING!  They were crispy and had a delicious flavor because they were hickory smoked.  They also came with a delicate drizzle of the most delicious sauce, I wish I knew the ingredients so I could re-create this dish.  I can't wait to come back to have them again!

I have always enjoyed myself here. I've dined and drank and drank and drank.

A few highlights of Radio are: 1) their Absinthe service, which is quite a production. I don't feel like I can really do it justice by describing it, but you will not be disappointed if you order up a couple Absinthe drinks. 2) They offer "The Wheel", which is a 3.5 oz shot of each of their beers on tap. They have about 28 beers on tap, and many are the darker craft ales, which in addition to being really tasty, are higher in proof. You need a couple of people to do this right, and there are some "rules", but if you are already planning on cabbing it home, this is a great way to learn about beer and get drunked. 3) Their kitchen stays open all night. 'nuff said. 4) Radio is one of the very best places to sit outside on a nice summer night. Get a table at dusk, put your back to the window and watch the night unfold.

Had brunch on Saturday, and it was so good we had to come back for more on Sunday. 

I had the vegetarian masa boat on Saturday, and it was absolutely delicious. The eggs were a wonderful texture, and it comes with a really great helping of goat cheese - always a plus IMO. Also had to order a side of beer bread and fried plantains, both good. The mexican coffee had a really nice flavor - I would recommend it over their regular coffee.

I had the omelet special on Sunday - blue crab, corn, celery, red pepper, with hollandaise on top. Amazing flavors, really great crab. Ordered a side of corn bread (drizzled with honey and orange marmalade), and that was pretty nice as well. Had a guava mimosa - not as much guava flavor as I had hoped, but can't argue too much with a nice helping of champagne!

I want to come back soon, especially because we saw these beakers mounted to the wall in the bar area, and our waiter told us it was their own strawberry rum.

Nice spot to grab a nice drink with friends or self ...a regular hangout for the local college students whom seem to handle their liquor pretty well. I'm sure this place serve food during normal business hours but a live DJ spins the latest current and throwback hiphop and urban music. Warning: no dance floor but clear a few chairs and take to the walkway and cut up a rug or two.  Drinks were decent and competitively priced ...we did patron shots and a variety of other drinks. My favorite drink of choice, which they made perfectly, is a Patron Margarita ...it was delicious. P.s ...this was on a Friday night by the way (the crowd was off and on all night but became nicely crowed around 1pm until the lights came on at 2am).

Another update -- I wish this place was more consistent.  We actually had a nice tapas dinner about a month ago, and I've grown to really like the beer bar.  I enjoyed, particularly, the patas bravas (although I'm pretty sure they were using liquid smoke, although if I'm wrong please let me know).  I'm going to leave it as 2 stars now since consistency we've had such an up and down experience over the last few months, but I'll give it some more chances in the future...
Vegetarian dishes were very good.  The paella was not worth the cost.  Paella need more meat or seafood and could use some vegetables as well.  Services were good

My first visit to champaign and our host took us here.  I order Sangria and it is so good, not too sweet not too bitter, just right for me. Their seafood is nice and fresh and the chocolate molten is a good finish for the meal.  I like the vibe in the restaurant and the outdoor seating is a plus to the the restaurant

Great place for tapas in Champaign. I agree that it's a good 'date night' place. Coming from Chicago, I find the portions of tapas to be large and inexpensive- which is great! They also have regular entrees if small plates aren't your thing. They had a good wine list, and the sangria was different ( I think there is brandy in it?) but good nonetheless. This is also a great vegetarian spot.

First time here...and I've heard great things about this place. First impressions were pretty good....the ambiance was good and the restaurant had a good amount of people. We started off ordering a tapas as our appetizer...the apple salad. It was very disappointing. The apples were not cut to order and were not crisp even though it was stored in a container of lemon juice. The bacon was not reheated...I mean who likes cold bacon? For pur entrees we ordered the scallops and duck meatloaf. The scallops were good however I personally didnt appreciate the jam that went with it...could have done with a spicy savory sauce. The duck was unknowingly served with the same exact jam. It was a tad too sweet for our tastes, but regardless of that...the meatloaf was absolutely amazing. The egg that topped it however was a bit overcooked so the sunnyside up yolk could not be used as a sauce. Our final conclusion is that the main part of the entreeswere cooked to order, as they should be, but all the garnish was precooked and we got the feeling that it was just thrown on...not worth the price.

Cheese balls with mushroom, goat cheese. This place was out of this world with the creativeness of the appetizers. I'd definitely go back there and continue to explore their menu. The drinks were very good and from what I can remember there's more I need to explore on that front also!

The atmosphere of this restaurant is a combination of modern hippie chic. There is beautifully hand crafted bar that encompasses colored glass, various rotating art strung throughout, and exposed brick.  

I had the Brier Patch to drink (I hope I remembered the name correctly).  Watching the bartender make it, I could see how much pride she took in creating the various meticulous drinks and I was not disappointed.  It was full of berry flavor without being overly sweet.

For dinner I ordered scallops on top of a fried risotto pancake with layer of arugula and goat cheese. The scallops were cooked perfectly and cut like butter. I can't describe the taste of my dish except that it was like nothing that I have ever had before.

I highly recommend that you come and check out this restaurant. If I am ever in town again I will be back!
Enjoy the brunch here on Sundays but that is usually the only time we eat here. The Lloyds omelet is great and you can sub grits or a biscuit for beer bread if you ask. Good draft beer selection.

Radio Maria is good. Not great, but good. 
Their brunches are much better than their dinners, and I'd probably give them a 4 for brunch. There are some good things to be found for dinner, but you have to search. The menus are a bit unwieldy.
No complaints on the cocktails at all, and they always have a really good beer selection. I'd be more inclined to come here for drinks or brunch than I would for dinner.
And, one bizarre thing that I can't get past - their cheese plates. Who puts feta on a cheese plate? There are lots of good cheeses around this area, so it seems crazy to have a below-average cheese plate.

I am straight up in LOVE with the fried goat cheese balls at radio maria. i was super excited to go and enjoy some of the deliciousness that is the food, however, last week i went in with a friend and we were seated and then literally sat there for 7 minutes before someone came over to us. I was just the hostess, who said that a waiter would be over in a minute. That minute was another 7 minutes, and we didn't even have a drink order in, so we got up to leave (as we were super hungry.) The hostess shrugged and was totally unapologetic about the terrible service, so we went to jupiter's and had some delicious pizza and beers for 1/4 the price of what we were going to order.

This is a neat place. They have some excellent food with one of the better drink menus in town. Their beer selection is hard to beat. They have plenty to please the roving beer snobs. I can always find an obscure beer that I've never encountered. One of my favorite up-scale places in the area.

The food was solid but the service, the last couple of times I was there, was a little lacking.  The servers were not all that attentive to our needs and our drinks were never refilled through the meal.  This place is a local favorite and definitely somewhere to visit.

I'm starting to think these guys spread themselves a bit too thin.

At brunch yesterday we were overwhelmed by how many options there were, with 14 regular offerings or so, about eight different omelettes, and then a dozen specials.  Yikes! 

Unfortunately, most of us were underwhelmed with the food.  My wife's Italian omelette lacked a kick--add some fresh garlic, perhaps?  The two of us whose dishes included the "house made" chorizo were disappointed at the sausage's lack of flavor--either spice it up or use store-bought, folks!

The mediocre food was made up for by the wonderful decor and overall experience.  As a Chicagoan with family in Champaign I'm jealous that a place like this exists, so inexpensive, with so much variety on the menu and 37 beers on tap (next door at the Tapas Bar)!  If they spent some time tweaking the dishes they have and adding that extra something many of them miss, they could become a truly top-notch restaurant for brunch.

UPDATE: Went to the tapas-bar portion of RM the other night and was really pleased with the dishes.  A few traditional tapas but mostly inventive twists using spanish ingredients, like lightly battered asparagus with serrano ham and manchego cheese and seared avocado  stuffed with quinoa.  Really tasty stuff, and goes great with one of the 25 draft beers (most of which cost four bucks).

This is our favorite brunch spot. They always have rotating specials for me, the adventurous one and biscuits and gravy for my boyfriend. The Flaming Frida is delicious. Don't waste your time on the bloody mary bar. They never have any garnishes that are worth the money - no meats and cheeses here. Thats my main complaint, the bloody marys don't have enough garnishes. You're lucky to get an olive. I will also say that, depending on the day, the service can be really slow.

Our whole family loves Spanish food and since we were all in Champaign for the football game we decided to check out a "new to us" Tapas restaurant.

When we arrived at 2:45, the kitchen was not open but would reopen in 15 minutes.  We decided we could easily wait so we snagged two tables outside and ordered drinks.  The waiter delivered the drinks and took our tapas order so he could put in the order as soon as the kitchen opened which was a marvelous idea!  Before you knew it we were sipping on Sangria and our food began to arrive.

We tried the cheese plate which was outstanding.  I could have just eaten that and been happy.  The mussels were grilled which had a pleasant taste but the grilling did dry them out.  The biggest disappointment was the Spanish tortilla, the traditional egg and potato omelet of Spain.  This had been prepared like more of a quiche and no one at the table liked or ate it.  I adored the fantastic lamb meatballs, we even ate the sauce with some of the bread which came with the cheese plate.  The other tapa I tried were the marinated olives which were not nearly as good as I had expected.  The marinade was so vinegary, not a smooth flavor at all.  I would not order that again.  We shared everything but there were some dishes I didn't try as I had ordered paella for my entree.

The paella was really really good.  It had a spicy chorizo but it did not overpower the overall rich saffron/olive oil taste of the dish.  The rice part was outstanding and the chicken and seafood were generous and tender. What a treat!  I had partaken of too many tapas so my husband had to finish mine, now that is a generous portion.

We had a great meal, my sangria mellowed me out after like 4 sips, the Illini had won and the weather was beautiful.  When the sizable check arrived I might have blanched at bit under normal circumstances but my husband and I just laughed and put it on a credit card.

It was a great meal with the family but very expensive.   Next game, those kids are getting pizza or burgers!  

 ¡Olé!

Went there for brunch , hot cinnamon rolls were fantastic  all three in our party had the same thing which was the radio Maria stack. Which had everything you want In a big breakfast   By the way it was delicious. Waiter was very friendly also
Forgot to mention  the interior design of this place was very attractive and comfortable

Reservation DOESN'T mean you are getting a seat! Our reservation was half an hour ago, the hostess still hasn't seated us. Her attitude was despicable and she insisted that reservation only means that you get priority over walk-ins and NOT a seat of your reserved time. Does she not know what the word reservation mean??? The point of making a reservation is getting a table at the reserved time!

REVIEW FOR BRUNCH ONLY

I love the hipster/retro ambience of Radio Maria, but I was definitely less impressed with their brunch. They have a large menu ranging from more traditional (i.e., eggs benedict) to more Spanish inspired (i.e., tamales) dishes. I tried the pork posole but found it to be rather lacking in pork flavor. The pork came shredded on the side, which I think is the first mistake: how are you supposed to infuse that meat flavor without cooking it in the stew? My friend said her pulled pork dish lacked some flavor as well, so maybe that's a theme here. On top of that, my poached eggs were seriously undercooked. There's nothing more disturbing than cutting into your eggs to see cloudy egg whites run into your stew...I will give a shout out to their beer bread, though. It's dense, moist, and they sear it on both sides to give an extra little crunchy texture. I'd come back for that alone.

I also tried their Flaming Maria, which is a bloody mary made with their house-infused tequila (infused with dill, garlic, hot peppers, and I can't remember what else). It was delish, but only get this if you're able to handle the heat because it was spicy, even by my standards!

Take home: come to Radio Maria for the beer bread, cocktails, and retro ambience, but I would skip the food.

This place is honestly a world class Spanish food/Tapas place.  The service is always awesome and they have a constantly changing menu that always includes things like cheese plates, steaks, fish, frog legs, with their goat cheese boursin stuff in lots of things.  Another reason going there is their great bar that has a beer selection which will please anyone who is as geeky about american craft beer as I am :-)

I'm not sure way anyone couldn't give this unique place 5 Stars!!  I'm from here, but have lived in LA for 35 years.  Radio Maria is better than most LA restaurants!!
The food was amazing we had Pork Tacos !!  So delish!  I had the "Sea Glass" Pinot which is new for me but so smooth and pleasing.  There was a guy in the corner which started putting on some enticing music!  Our Bartender was on top of it!!  I just can't recommend this place more highly!!  Check it out!!
I've been a few times for drinks and tapas and Radio Maria is fine, good even, but it just feels a little pretentious and fussy sometimes. I really want to like the place more but I just don't.
I had a boss who was obsessed with this place.  They have good hummus and I like the fried plantains.  Otherwise, it's fine.  Brunch is the best time to go.

Four stars for atmosphere on the bar side.  Four stars for the service at the bar and at the tables.  5 stars for the Green Curry Hot Pot...should've ordered 2!  Man that is a fine and tasty dish!  Phenomenal draft selection and craft drinks, plus quality on the old standbys.  #winning

I love Radio Maria! I used to go here with my parents sometimes when they came to visit me as a student. This weekend my husband and I were in town for a board meeting and had a pleasant dinner. We sat outside because the weather was great.

Delicious mojitos for both of us. We had the roasted garlic on toast, a potatoes with chorizo and egg tapas, and the filet mignon entree special with roasted brussels sprouts and pearl onions, radishes, mustard and cheddar. Absolutely to die for!!

We will definitely return on another trip to the CU.
I believe they got a new chef semi recently... Didn't think much of this place a few years ago but now think it's one of the best spots for a good dinner in c-u

Radio Maria has great and unique food! I went on a date here and absolutely loved it! Every dish is most likely something you would never think of creating but it will be soo good!  The selection of wines is excellent as well!

I absolutely love Radio Maria. Delicious and unique food, very cool artsy atmosphere, and wonderful service (Aaron is my favorite!). I go here for every special occasion. The tapas and brunch are both fantastic, and the bar is good too. The artwork that decorates the place was all made by local artists. They play good music as well (jazz and chill electronic music mostly). My favorites here are the arancini, patatas, and the Mexican coffee. 

Absolutely can't say enough good things about this place, I can't believe it only has 3.5 stars on Yelp. Just too many salty people leaving bad reviews I guess!

Been there many times over the years, and the restaurant went down the hill. Service is awful and very slow, portions small, ingredients often inferior, and food overpriced for its quality and portion size. Seared tuna was not even chewable, lamb balls dry, potato tapas prepared ma-a-any days before we visited. They used to have tasty ox tail as tapas; now it disappeared, though remains on the menu, and the waiters lie that "we ran out of it today." The only reason to go is a huge list of draft beers.

HORRIBLE service tonight. Fifteen minutes to get three draft beers? Twenty minutes to get the check? While we were waiting we saw our waiter standing around and talking to another server and our beers were sitting on the bar getting warm. We got there at 5pm and were the only table and left at 6:30ish when there couldn't have been more than 7 or 8 tables.

Food was good. But not worth the price for the bad waitstaff.

I've eaten here on average of around eight times a year since 2007. I've come to the conclusion that Radio Maria doesn't care about not being good because they've established their niche in a town with so few good options, allowing them to stay in business despite the downside. 

I've always had really good servers and bartenders here. Some of the menu dishes can be really good, but subject to inconsistent execution. Some of the menu dishes are downright bad by any standard. A vanilla cream sauce doesn't complement goat cheese, for example. It isn't interesting. It's just kind of awful.

Radio Maria is one of my favorite Sunday brunch spots in the area. 

The Mexican coffee is quite sweet, so you may want to avoid it if you don't typically take sugar with your coffee. 

The highlight of the Migas dish would be the black beans - they are so well seasoned and contain a hint of lime. The eggs contain a good amount and variety of vegetables. 

The vegetarian eggs benedict was also tasty. The eggs were poached perfectly and we're paired well with the soft avocados and tomatoes. The house potatoes are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside - just the way I liked them. 

Radio Maria can definitely accommodate large parties, and I would recommend making a reservation ahead of time to avoid a wait!

Made the mistake of coming here for brunch Homecoming weekend. The service was incredibly slow. Took over an hour to get two breakfast dishes. I didn't get drinks but it did seem like people were enjoying their drinks orders. 

I ordered huevos rancheros with chorizo which is something I thought was hard to mess up. After the wait I was expecting greatness but this restaurant did not deliver. Eggs were over salted and the presentation was not appealing. Don't think I'll be back again.

I've never had tapas before so there's might not be too much credibility in my review but the food was okay. portions were small and very expense. We ordered a paella ($20) but it came out to be the size of a small tapas so that was kind of disappointing. The servers were super friendly and hipster so definitely fun people to talk to. The wine was really good and the environment was top notch. However, I don't think i will be coming back but it was definitely something I wanted to experience at least once living in Champaign.

Had brunch there on Sunday with 8 people.  1 vegetarian and 1 very picky eater.  We loved it.  Everything was spectacular.  Only downfall - not enough of the potatoes which were incredible!  Had the smoked trout omelette which was soooo good.

Food is solidly good but not brilliant compared to tapas places I've been in other towns.  That being said I enjoyed the food and definitely will come back - it's creative, fresh, and varied.
Kind of weird to have two kitchens/two menus that aren't coordinated - they start with an apology for it.
Wine and beer list is plenty long and varied - flavors for everyone.  Plus, Tuesday is 1/2 off wine by the glass night - how can you beat that?
Specials were very tasty - Mahi-mahi in parchment, and a local organic heirloom tomato salad w/orange zest and balsamic - yummy!
Outside tables are great on a warm summer evening.
Service at times a bit slow although great service attitude and personality by our server - as with any restaurant it depends on the person you get and the night you go...
Agree with 3+ stars.

Let me walk you through my dining experience this morning. We arrived at the restaurant at 11:40 am, waited to be greeted by the hostess, waited while the hostess decided where to seat us, and she abruptly walked away from the hostess stand without a word and expected us to follow so eventually we did, she had no clue where she planned to seat us so we walked around the entire restaurant following her like kids who had no friends at lunchtime. We had no water or no greeting from any server or bus boy until 20 minutes after we arrived. Our server finally arrived and gave a weak apology and blamed the hostess for the reason he didn't acknowledge us. We finally ordered and waited 45 minutes for food only for us to be served only 2/3 of our meals with us not having any silverware, as we waited for our silverware and as our food got cold we noticed one of our meals were made incorrectly after the server argued that it was right he finally took it back and when he returned he told us that our third meal one was dropped and they couldn't remake it so we waited for a replacement meal and one member of our party had to sit and watch the other two eat for 20 minutes while she waited for her meal. I was disgusted when they handed us our checks at the end of the meal, I was sure that atleast they would've comped the Neal we waited over an hour for and when I brought this concern up to the server he said "every one here has been waiting over an hour so it's not anything different". I proceeded to ask for management and after waiting another 15 minutes we were greeted by a "manager" but we frequent this restaurant and have had him as our server on server all occasions, so that was shameful enough. Then both the server named Jeanluc and the "manager", a shorter bald African American man who didn't offer his name, proceeded to literally yell at us. When we didn't back down he yelled out "I'll fix it" and stormed off. No apology, no concern, nothing. 2 hours wasted.

I have never had a more frustrating and disappointed experience, I have also never not tipped a server as I have worked as one before and I understand people and restaurants have bad days but this was uncanny. Not one staff member was nice or accommodating, the "manager" was the worst of them all. I work at the only hotel in the downtown champaign area and not only do I usually recommend this place to my friends but also to the guests who visit champaign, and you can guarantee this is so far removed from my recommendation list. I will NOT be back, and will try to save my friends and guests from being treated as I just was too.
Friendly, quick. We were in before dinner norm hours.  Small portion on garlic shrimp , pork tacos stale shell. Salsa was tasty, pork bland.  Nice looking place.

The food seems extremely simple for their prices. I have eaten brunch and dinner here and the food is really not that amazing.   The drinks are always good and I never go downtown without having a little white lie!

Love this place!  Went there for a late dinner.  Love the bar, love the atmosphere.  Ate off the Tapas Menu....Food was the best!!! The Scallops melted in your mouth! Wine was great...service was great!  Can't wait to go back!

Awesome beer and wine selection, probably one of the best in the city. I mean, they serve absinthe! The atmosphere is great, very nicely lit inside, the bar its awesome, and they always have some crazy art on the walls.

I also really love their tapas, it's a great spot to go on a date. Everything I've had there was suuuuper delicious. I also love their specials and they seem to have new ones all the time.

5 for service. You get this blond hair female bartender, go to her!!!  She's totally awesome and makes good recommendation.  Food isn't bad either. 

Why the 4 stars?  Yo, I ordered the chocolate de wannabe creme brûlée thingamajig and it only came with two slits of ginger snaps cookies (like the kind you pay 3 bucks for at ikea). I ordered two more of them rectangles and they charged me 50 cents!  They charged me 50 cents for two rectangles of a graham cracker (remember a whole graham cracker has 4 rectangles).  Man, as I eat those cookies I lost my appetite for the dessert (rarely happens). I didn't even want to take it home.  I felt like I got carjacked and I wasn't even driving. Carjacked by ginger snap cookies, from ikea!!! Wtf!? 

Ahhh, but I'll be back. I'll just stay away from them cookies.

My friend and I went here for brunch. Everything was delicious! I got the caprese omelet, and my friend got the lobster omelet. The beer bread and potatoes that come with the omelet were so good! We also tried the mexican coffee. It doesn't taste that good with the food. It tastes better on its own. It's something you won't regret trying. It's sweet and has a strong cinnamon flavor. Service was pretty slow, but we were okay with that this time. I highly recommend going to Radio Maria for brunch! I would love to try their lunch and dinner menu as well :)

Our server (tall, slender, red-headed male in late 20s-early 30s) was SHIT HAMMERED and it made our dining experience very awkward!!! He forgot nearly everything that we asked for and we had to remind him several times to put in our drink and food orders. He kept apologizing and making excuses that he was busy... but there were very few other customers in the restaurant!! He had no idea what the specials were. He didn't know the difference between our drinks when he finally brought them to the table. At one point, he plopped down next to me in the booth and was mumbling something and drunkenly pointing at the menu and his breath was UNBEARABLE in my face!!! When we finally got our food, he went to the bar area and creepily watched us as we tried to enjoy it. He "check up" on us every 3-4 minutes and kept trying to take our drinks that were still half full. We tried to be polite and just get through dinner without making a scene - we just wanted him to leave us alone!! I don't even remember how the food was because we were so UNCOMFORTABLE. We will absolutely NOT be returning as customers.

The ambience at the bar is really exceptional.  We always sit at the bar for tapas.. You must be in an experimental mood, this food is nowhere near "normal bar food".  The sea scallops and the seared tuna will make you crave more.  The bartender can accomodate any request, with a passion.  We have him making key lime pie martinis, and they rock.   Fun place. Ultra Cool. Super Hip.

On a return trip from the mid west, we were lucky to walk into Radio Maria.  From the outside it wasn't very impressive.  Once inside, we took a seat a the bar.  The bartender was really knowledgeable and there was a great selection of beer, wine and spirits.  The menu runs from an inventive tapas list to unique entrees.  We were blown away by both the house smoked pork tacos and the duck breast salad.  
Between the wonderful bar and the outstanding food, we will be stopping back next time we are able to come through Champaign!

I loved the decor in the new Radio Maria Tapas bar, but I was NOT crazy about the tapas.  The olives in our manchego baked olive dish had a bizarre citrus note that was rather offputting, and were way short on manchego.  Our apple blue cheese spread appeared to be apple-free, and the blue cheese spread itself was runny.  

My bloody mary was top notch; I'll have to do some serious research to figure out whether it surpasses guido's for best bloody mary down town.
Addicting Brunch. MANY veggie options

I'll give you reasons to visit Radio Maria if you haven't already:

1. It's one of the better places in downtown CU. Great date spot, low nights, vintage-y decor (I believe they took old theater parts and gave them a modern twist). Friendly servers, not sure about the hosts, but hey! The hosts won't be serving you anyway.
2. Go so you can say you have, then you can write your own snobby bullet point review. Go for dinner, not brunch.
3. Be safe, use Yelp protection. You can't go dislike tapas or any of the steak entrees (unless you're vegetarian). Also, give ox tail a try. You'll wish you started chasing tail earlier.
